commit_message:
Basic support for image conversion

This patch adds a task for image conversion. It uses `qemu-img` to
convert images. This tool has support for several image formats.

The current implementation converts images if and only if the operator
has configured glance to do so. That is, the `convert_to_format` option
has been set.

There are few things about this patch that should be improved by
follow-up patches. The first one is the fact that it relies on the
entry_points order for task execution. Although this works, it is not
the most flexible/controllable way to do it. The second thing is that it
relies on the aforementioned configuration option to enable/disable the
task (as in, it becomes a non-op). There should be an explicit way to
enable/disable tasks.

Since both things mentioned in the previous paragraph affect the task
management in general, I've decided to leave the fix for a follow-up
patch.

DocImpact
SecurityImpact

Partially-implements blueprint: new-upload-workflow
Partially-implements blueprint: basic-import-conversion

Change-Id: I0196a6f327c0147f897ae051ee60a8cb11b8fd40
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/29/159129/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Implements whitelist and blacklist mapping rules

Adds whitelist and blacklist rules to allow passing through a list of
groups from the IdP, after filtering them according to either of these
rules.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte Sousa <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: David Stanek <dstanek@dstanek.com>
Partially-Implements: bp mapping-enhancements
Change-Id: I4592ba1c05e99c16645b5303c0192fc462b474aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/73/142573/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEVELOPER_GROUP_NAME = "Developer" CONTRACTOR_GROUP_NAME = "Contractor"MAPPING_GROUPS_WHITELIST = { 'rules': [ { "remote": [ { "type": "orgPersonType", "whitelist": [ "Developer", "Contractor" ] }, ], "local": [ { "groups": "{0}", "domain": { "id": DEVELOPER_GROUP_DOMAIN_ID } }, ] } ] } MAPPING_GROUPS_BLACKLIST = { 'rules': [ { "remote": [ { "type": "orgPersonType", "blacklist": [ "Developer", "Manager" ] }, ], "local": [ { "groups": "{0}", "domain": { "id": DEVELOPER_GROUP_DOMAIN_ID } }, ] } ] } MAPPING_GROUPS_WHITELIST_AND_BLACKLIST = { 'rules': [ { "remote": [ { "type": "orgPersonType", "blacklist": [ "Employee" ], "whitelist": [ "Contractor" ] }, ], "local": [ { "groups": "{0}", "domain": { "id": DEVELOPER_GROUP_DOMAIN_ID } }, ] } ] } EMPLOYEE_ASSERTION_MULTIPLE_GROUPS = { 'Email': 'tim@example.com', 'UserName': 'tbo', 'FirstName': 'Tim', 'LastName': 'Bo', 'orgPersonType': 'Developer;Manager;Contractor' }

subject: DB changes for resource locking
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-20 06:11:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/ea1f268ea786ebbe4cee52cefcb2e8a65cc3b86c', 'message': 'DB changes for resource locking

This patch adds engine_id column to the resource table for locking
the resource. Also added the db api required to create, acquire
and release the lock.

commit_message:
DB changes for resource locking

This patch adds engine_id and atomic_key column to the resource
table for locking the resource and making all operations atomic.
Also added the db api to update the resource table.

The engine which updates the db first, gets the lock on the
resource. Only updates with this engine are possible. Updates with
other engine will not go through as they will fail to find the
matching record in the db.

Change-Id: Id8c3df7a439347652d3feca7481cd72762bf30ea
Implements: blueprint convergence-resource-locking
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/72/157672/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: engine_id = sqlalchemy.Column(sqlalchemy.String(36))

commit_message:
Bump rtslib version to have config persistence

On version 2.1.41 method save_to_file was added and it is now need to
persist iSCSI lio configuration.

Change-Id: I0cac2ebb709089181b237fe6df94a44a30be716e
Related-Bug: #1427301

commit_message:
Add missing servers.create parameter documentation

The min_count, max_count, and security_groups parameters for
servers.create are missing documentation. The security_groups
parameter was documented in the servers._boot function but that
private function isn't published to the docs.

This change adds the missing documentation for the aforementioned
parameters and removes the duplicate docs in the servers._boot
function.

Change-Id: Ib0dcc7e8f7f4d0b83b6caeddd1ace66add4e0003

commit_message:
Fixes alignment of pencil icon in Users Table

When cell is empty (e.g. in the email column), the edit pencil icon gets
shifted down and not centered. This patch makes the pencil icon centered
for all the cases.

Change-Id: I5a344449e496e73f2a0679a6206e4c35747afb0f
Closes-bug: #1419204

commit_message:
Adding utf8 to federation tables

Tables have to be in utf8 for the migration utility
to work properly. This fixes the UTF8 issues with the
federation tables in-line and should be able to be
backported. A subsequent change to handle sanity checks
in a more sane way (post migrations) will be implemented
going forward.

Change-Id: Id68c3f307f53b6a4de011e2608d899d044aced68
Closes-Bug: 1426334

commit_message:
Refactor '_get_default_network' method in the integration tests

Refactored '_get_default_network' to get any network by its name,
othewise it was impossible to get 'public' net.

Change-Id: Ie691f99961a28e47f7437f3e52be9baf2984e839

commit_message:
Add multiattach capabilities injection

This patch is a follow up to the multiattach patch that adds
the ability to the scheduler to be able to filter capabilities
on the volume multiattach flag.   When a volume creation request
comes in with the multiattach flag set on a volume, there was no
way to filter out backends that don't support attaching a volume
to more than one host.   By defaut, no host supports it.  When
The Nova side lands, we can adjust drivers to add the new
multiattach:True capability reporting.

Change-Id: Ia426a2bf2ab8214f52fb6e70a3a1deff68d13d98
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/50/159650/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Does this backend support attaching a volume to more than # once host/instance? self.multiattach = False

commit_message:
Add InstanceList.get_all method

As part of the effort to remove direct DB calls from the Scheduler
filters, there needs to be a method for getting an InstanceList object
containing all the instances available.

Partially-Implements: blueprint isolate-scheduler-db
(https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/isolate-scheduler-db)

added_lines: @mock.patch('nova.db.instance_get_all') def test_get_all(self, mock_get_all): fakes = [self.fake_instance(1), self.fake_instance(2)] mock_get_all.return_value = fakes inst_list = instance.InstanceList.get_all(self.context) for i in range(0, len(fakes)): self.assertIsInstance(inst_list.objects[i], instance.Instance) self.assertEqual(inst_list.objects[i].uuid, fakes[i]['uuid']) self.assertRemotes() def test_find_by_uuid(self): fake1 = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context, uuid='fake1') fake2 = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context, uuid='fake2') inst_list = instance.InstanceList(objects=[fake1, fake2]) found = inst_list.find_by_uuid('fake2') self.assertEqual(found, fake2) found = inst_list.find_by_uuid('does not exist') self.assertIsNone(found) def test_pop_by_uuid(self): fake1 = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context, uuid='fake1') fake2 = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context, uuid='fake2') inst_list = instance.InstanceList(objects=[fake1, fake2]) self.assertEqual(len(inst_list.objects), 2) popped = inst_list.pop_by_uuid('fake2') self.assertEqual(popped, fake2) self.assertEqual(len(inst_list.objects), 1) popped = inst_list.pop_by_uuid('does not exist') self.assertIsNone(popped) self.assertEqual(len(inst_list.objects), 1)

Changes:
- Create the disk-image-builder elements for
  installing HP Vertica on Ubuntu.

- Introduces new env variables:
  - DS_WITH_MANUAL_PACKAGE: Signifies that the datastores
    in this list need a manually downloaded package file.
  - DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION: Specifies location to look for
    package installer file for datastores in
    DS_WITH_MANUAL_PACKAGE list, which by-default would look
    in a pkgs directory in user's home.

- If a datastore is listed in DS_WITH_MANUAL_PACKAGE and
  package file does not exists at DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION then
  kick-start would error out by informing
  "Datastore package file not found! Download package file
  for datastore: <DATASTORE_NAME>"

- To execute kick-start for Vertica, user has to download
  Vertica package from https://my.vertica.com and place
  the file at DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION.

Partially Implements: blueprint vertica-db-support

Change-Id: Ibc64b42eb5d2f4722eb27a7bc730dda98014347f

To execute kick-start for Vertica, user has to download

commit_message:
Create DIB elements for HP Vertica on Ubuntu

A specification for this change was submitted for review in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151126/

Changes:
- Creates the disk-image-builder elements for
  installing HP Vertica on Ubuntu.

- Introduces new env variables DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION which
  specifies location to look for package installer file.

- It would be the job of elements(extra-data.d) to discover
  existence of DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION, and notify appropriate
  error message in case of non-existent DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION.

To execute kick-start for Vertica, user has to download
Vertica package from https://my.vertica.com and place
file at DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION and update the value of
DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION to point to actual package-file.

For eg.
if package file-name is vertica.deb and it is placed in /tmp,
then to run kick-start proceed as follows:

  $ export DATASTORE_PKG_LOCATION=/tmp/vertica.deb
  $ ./redstack kick-start vertica

Partially Implements: blueprint vertica-db-support

Change-Id: Ibc64b42eb5d2f4722eb27a7bc730dda98014347f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/49/156149/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # CONTEXT: HOST prior to IMAGE BUILD as SCRIPT USER # PURPOSE: stages the VERTICA_PACKAGE_FILE file, so that guest image has the package file. set -e set -o xtrace source $_LIB/die [ -n "$TMP_HOOKS_PATH." ] || die "Temp hook path not set" dd if=${VERTICA_SOURCE}/${VERTICA_PACKAGE_FILE} of=${TMP_HOOKS_PATH}/${VERTICA_PACKAGE_FILE}

commit_message:
Add a in-memory backend dumping example

Change-Id: Ie29735a16129cedd574e09ed06b44a98560f0d90
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/57/163657/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (C) 2015 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import os import sys logging.basicConfig(level=logging.ERROR) self_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__)) top_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), os.pardir, os.pardir)) sys.path.insert(0, top_dir) sys.path.insert(0, self_dir) from taskflow import engines from taskflow.patterns import linear_flow as lf from taskflow.persistence import backends from taskflow import task from taskflow.utils import persistence_utils as pu # INTRO: in this example we create a dummy flow with a dummy task, and run # it using a in-memory backend and pre/post run we dump out the contents # of the in-memory backends tree structure (which can be quite useful to # look at for debugging or other analysis). class PrintTask(task.Task): def execute(self): print("Running '%s'" % self.name) backend = backends.fetch({ 'connection': 'memory://', }) book, flow_detail = pu.temporary_flow_detail(backend=backend) # Make a little flow and run it... f = lf.Flow('root') for alpha in ['a', 'b', 'c']: f.add(PrintTask(alpha)) e = engines.load(f, flow_detail=flow_detail, book=book, backend=backend) e.compile() e.prepare() print("----------") print("Before run") print("----------") print(backend.memory.pformat()) print("----------") e.run() print("---------") print("After run") print("---------") for node in backend.memory.dfs_iter(): print(node.item) print(node.metadata)

commit_message:
Restructure the in-memory node usage

Instead of retaining full paths only retain
partial paths; this then allows for finding
a parent node and then easily finding a child
by using the find() routines.

This more naturally emulates a real filesystem
using our tree structure and simplifies certain
operations to make them more efficient/simple.

Change-Id: I207b02c979704a15eac8be46d11a0af61b05d9b9

subject: Bring EC API calls in sync with PyECLib 1.0
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-11 17:22:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/4f97a3629777611e1a0669484c34ac826cf00c12', 'message': 'Bring EC API calls in sync with PyECLib 1.0

Changes in PyECLib 1.0:

  * All PyECLib exceptions consolidated into one (ECDriverError)
    with improved error handling
  * Uses liberasurecode-provided EC backends
    (some semantic/error reporting changes)
  * EC backend names brought in sync with liberasurecode
    (flat_xor_3 -> flat_xor_hd_3,
     flat_xor_4 -> flat_xor_hd_4,
     jerasure_rs_cauchy_orig -> jerasure_rs_cauchy)

Change-Id: I941541f8043c8a4851815df654e467d42f00c357
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-11 20:24:39.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/common/test_storage_policy.py', 'test/unit/proxy/test_server.py', 'swift/common/storage_policy.py', 'doc/source/overview_erasure_code.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/719483a81f83391ee8471ea3dc50ffce933cfc27', 'message': 'Bring EC API calls in sync with PyECLib 1.0

commit_message:
Bring EC API calls in sync with PyECLib 1.0

Changes in PyECLib 1.0:

  * All PyECLib exceptions consolidated into one (ECDriverError)
    with improved error handling
  * Uses liberasurecode-provided EC backends
    (some semantic/error reporting changes)
  * EC backend names brought in sync with liberasurecode
    (flat_xor_3 -> flat_xor_hd_3,
     flat_xor_4 -> flat_xor_hd_4,
     jerasure_rs_cauchy_orig -> jerasure_rs_cauchy)

Change-Id: I941541f8043c8a4851815df654e467d42f00c357
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/33/163533/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * ec_type: set this value according to the available options in the selected PyECLib back-end. This specifies the EC scheme that is to be used. For example the option shown here selects Vandermonde Reed-Solomon encoding while an option of 'flat_xor_hd_3' would select Flat-XOR based HD combination codes. See the `PyECLib <https://bitbucket.org/kmgreen2/pyeclib>`_ page for full details.

commit_message:
Ensure a hypervisor is only managed by a single compute host

Nova does not support a hypervisor managed by more than 1 compute
host. This change makes that lack of support explicit by causing Nova
to raise an exception when attempting to create a compute node which
violates it. If the compute driver reports all nodes at startup, as
the VMware driver does, and Ironic can do, this will cause a
misconfigured Nova to fail to start. This is preferrable to allowing
the system to run, which will require manual cleanup and may result in
data loss.

Specifically, if the compute driver reports a hypervisor node from
get_available_nodes(), Nova assumes that all instances associated with
that node will also have the same compute host. This assumption is
pervasive, and violating it breaks a large number of things. The bug
below notes that the evacuation cleanup code will cause all instances
running on the hypervisor to be erroneously deleted. It will also
prevent all periodic tasks from running correctly.

There are currently only 2 drivers which report a hypervisor identity
different to the compute host: VMware and Ironic. No other drivers
are affected by this change.

Note that this change is not related to support for multiple
hypervisors per compute host. It relates to a single hypervisor being
accidentally managed by multiple compute hosts, which is not
supported.

Closes-Bug: #1419785
Change-Id: I48c2331e66532cd043da8aecdb8e7649776e836a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/158269/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Log stdout from build_wheels in cache_devstack

This commit adds a print statement with the stdout from the run_local()
call which executes build_wheels.sh in devstack. Right now when the
script is executed all it does is print that it's running but we are
unable to debug anything that could potentially go wrong during the
execution of the script without the output from build_wheels.

Change-Id: I7433f054127a42fa73598db219c6e351efc98fb7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/58/163958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: output = run_local(['bash', 'tools/build_wheels.sh'], cwd=DEVSTACK, env=env) print output

commit_message:
Update latest modules from oslo-incubator

Updates the _i18n, versionutils, and install_venv_common
modules to the latest from oslo-incubator. The other modules
listed in openstack-common.conf (lockutils, log, importlib, and
fixture) could not be found because they are not part of
oslo-incubator anymore. The log module was updated by hand to
fix a bug, but it and the other deprecated modules should be
replaced with the appropriate substitutions.

Change-Id: I14a7a31e7208a9dc5dbd5686fbeab824b455ffa8
Partial-Bug: 1430124

commit_message:
Make dependency on boto entirely conditional

By moving the import into the (only) method that needs boto.exception we
retain the ability to list the options from that driver without breaking
glance_store.backend.register_opts.

Closes-bug: 1426767
Change-Id: Ie35b4b41f71b79502cb2d4b83c2037ec0d798557
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/28/161428/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Temporary fix for being able to load neutron_lbaas.conf

This bug prevents neutron_lbaas.conf from being loaded and
we need this file to be loaded to gain access to the config options.
This is just a temporary solution and should immediately be undone
once a fix for the bug has been commited to neutron.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1430153

Change-Id: Idcdd09006613b77847d8fc83c2225ad3b0540c13

commit_message:
Fix for broken languagepack logs command

We need to use the print_list() method to display results,
not the print_dict() method.

Change-Id: I25994a969445059cde48400218c7a3e5fe6a2eca
Closes-bug: 1431528

commit_message:
Remove CLI tests from tempest plugin

Since CLI tests were implemented in manilaclient itself we do not need it
anymore in manila. So, remove it as duplication.

Change-Id: Ie6ff3e7e822276c247f73ab6495ca2a2acee91ce

commit_message:
lazy loading for logbooks and flowdetails

You can now specify a "lazy" argument when asking a
persistence backend for a logbook for flowdetail.
This will return a logbook with no flowdetails in it,
or a flowdetail with no atomdetails in it, respectively.

Change-Id: Ie81a19a2107b44e2c35c2a92507bec03eee55c50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/69/163269/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_logbook(self, book_uuid, lazy=False): if not lazy: self._converter.populate_book(conn, book) def get_logbooks(self, lazy=False): if not lazy: self._converter.populate_book(conn, book) def get_flows_for_book(self, book_uuid, lazy=False): for fd in self._converter.flow_query_iter(conn, book_uuid): if not lazy: self._converter.populate_flow_detail(conn, fd) gathered.append(fd) def get_flow_details(self, fd_uuid, lazy=False): fd = self._converter.convert_flow_detail(row) if not lazy: self._converter.populate_flow_detail(conn, fd) return fd
deleted_lines: def get_logbook(self, book_uuid): self._converter.populate_book(conn, book) def get_logbooks(self): self._converter.populate_book(conn, book) def get_flows_for_book(self, book_uuid): for row in self._converter.flow_query_iter(conn, book_uuid): flow_details = self._converter.populate_flow_detail(conn, row) gathered.append(flow_details) def get_flow_details(self, fd_uuid): return self._converter.convert_flow_detail(row)

commit_message:
Move policy enforcement into REST API layer for v2.1 extended_volumes

This patch moves the policy enforcement into REST API layer for v2.1
extend_volumes extension and adds related unittest.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib67e423aaf0d1878ebaa6d9a5304d1a757913dd5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/150258/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.api.openstack.compute.plugins.v3 import extended_volumesfrom nova.tests.unit.api import common class ExtendedVolumesEnforcementV21(test.NoDBTestCase, common.TestPolicyEnforcementBase): @common.TestPolicyEnforcementBase.policy_enforcement_failed_test( 'compute_extension:v3:os-extended-volumes:swap', 'project_id:non_fake') def test_swap_policy_failed(self): controller = extended_volumes.ExtendedVolumesController() self._call_controller_method(controller.swap, 'fake_id', body={'swap_volume_attachment': { 'old_volume_id': UUID1, 'new_volume_id': UUID1}}) @common.TestPolicyEnforcementBase.policy_enforcement_failed_test( 'compute_extension:v3:os-extended-volumes:attach', 'project_id:non_fake') def test_attach_policy_failed(self): controller = extended_volumes.ExtendedVolumesController() self._call_controller_method(controller.attach, 'fake_id', body={'attach': {'volume_id': UUID1}}) @common.TestPolicyEnforcementBase.policy_enforcement_failed_test( 'compute_extension:v3:os-extended-volumes:detach', 'project_id:non_fake') def test_detach_policy_failed(self): controller = extended_volumes.ExtendedVolumesController() self._call_controller_method(controller.detach, 'fake_id', body={'detach': {'volume_id': UUID1}})

commit_message:
Remove useless policy rules for v2.1 api which removed/disabled

Because V2.1 must be identical with V2 and must not contain any new
attributes and new method. So the swap/attach/deatch in extend_volume
was removed.  But there still left some policy rules related to it.
This patch cleanup them.

Change-Id: I6e7e3263261519f72fa6b067db6a5930026f02dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/89/163689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Allow injected atom args to be persisted
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-10 19:55:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/6609c1a00b03e68720e6f81ac47e5a2f152d5ec6', 'message': 'Allow injected atom args to be persisted (WIP)

Instead of only storing injected atom arguments in memory
allow for specifying those to be persisted; so that users
who desire this feature can persist them (it defaults to
being transient to retain the old API behavior).

Change-Id: I2846d0334db32a115592f850d85b206d9e6a3f07
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-10 20:10:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/6c7851280131be3828df9cdd21b2194e2439d388', 'message': 'Allow injected atom args to be persisted (WIP)

Instead of only storing injected atom arguments in memory
allow for specifying those to be persisted; so that users
who desire this feature can persist them (it defaults to
being transient to retain the old API behavior).

Change-Id: I2846d0334db32a115592f850d85b206d9e6a3f07
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-03-10 23:19:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/taskflow/commit/2f244cd02c7f8cf0dff6440d8f9c3eba198c8d24', 'message': 'Allow injected atom args to be persisted (WIP)

Instead of only storing injected atom arguments in memory
allow for specifying those to be persisted; so that users
who desire this feature can persist them (it defaults to
being transient to retain the old API behavior).

This also reworks the validating of engine dependencies
to be more correct. It removes the validation of these
dependencies from the prepare() method and moves them to a
new engine validate() method; this allows users to prepare()
the engine, then inject there atom non-transient arguments
and then validate(); the validation would fail prior to this
at preparation time since no injected arguments would
exist and the user would not have the ability to inject any
that target a specific atom, since the atom detail would
not have been created yet (since that is populated in the
prepartion method).

Change-Id: I2846d0334db32a115592f850d85b206d9e6a3f07

commit_message:
Allow injected atom args to be persisted

Instead of only storing injected atom arguments in memory
allow for specifying those to be persisted; so that users
who desire this feature can persist them (it defaults to
being transient to retain the old API behavior).

This also reworks the validating of engine dependencies
to be more correct. It removes the validation of these
dependencies from the prepare() method and moves them to a
new engine validate() method; this allows users to prepare()
the engine, then inject there atom non-transient arguments
and then validate(); the validation would fail prior to this
at preparation time since no injected arguments would
exist and the user would not have the ability to inject any
that target a specific atom, since the atom detail would
not have been created yet (since that is populated in the
prepartion method).

Change-Id: I2846d0334db32a115592f850d85b206d9e6a3f07

commit_message:
Allow backend connection config (via fetch) to be a string

To make it easier to provide just a connection string to the
persistence backend fetch mechanism (without needing to create
a dictionary with just a 'connection' key) match the behavior
of the other fetch-like functions and accept a string to
simplify the interaction with this function.

Change-Id: I59cd330c545985fe9782c3049690425ead1c8cf3

commit_message:
Add boto to requirements.txt.

On exec glance-api displayed exception "ImportError: No module named boto.exception".

% /usr/bin/glance-api
2015-02-28 15:21:25.949 23107 ERROR stevedore.extension [-] Could not load 's3': No module named boto.exception
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 ERROR stevedore.extension [-] No module named boto.exception
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension Traceback (most recent call last):
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/stevedore/extension.py", line 162, in _load_plugins
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension     verify_requirements,
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/stevedore/extension.py", line 185, in _load_one_plugin
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension     plugin = ep.load(require=verify_requirements)
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources.py", line 2025, in load
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension     entry = __import__(self.module_name, globals(),globals(), ['__name__'])
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glance_store/_drivers/s3.py", line 26, in <module>
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension     import boto.exception
2015-02-28 15:21:25.950 23107 TRACE stevedore.extension ImportError: No module named boto.exception

boto does not exist to glance_store requirements.

After boto installation, issue was fixed.

Change-Id: Idc11d10e7ded41ef2b934f8c93df1e101828cd84
Closes-Bug: #1426767

commit_message:
Run nodepool-coverage as a check job

We are currently working to make nodepool much better tested. Add a
coverage job to the check queue so that we can see how we are doing as
we add new tests.

Change-Id: Ib47763b35b11d8f794bfa5352fdab449d7d7d66a

Instead of using always using a set/dict which do not retain
ordering allow for atoms to override the dict and set types
to be other compatible types, such as a ordered set and a ordered
dict to be used for requires, optional, and provides and rebind
mappings types so that the ordering of these containers is
maintained later when they are used.

These ordering can be useful depending on the atom type (such
as in a map and reduce tasks). By default we just retain the
existing types, but allow for others to subclass and replace
them with compatible types as needed.

commit_message:
Use ordered[set/dict] to retain ordering

Instead of using always using a set/dict which do not retain
use a ordered set and a ordered dict for requires, optional,
and provides and rebind mappings types so that the ordering
of these containers is maintained later when they are used.

These ordering can be useful depending on the atom type (such
as in a map and reduce tasks).

Partial-Bug: 1357117

Change-Id: I365d11bbba4aa221bc36ca15441acecf199b4d56

commit_message:
Add support for identity_uri.

This patch adds the ability to set a new keystone_identity_uri
parameter.  It also deprecates the old keystone_host, keystone_port,
keystone_protocol, and keystone_auth_admin_prefix parameters. Logic
is in place so that users of the deprecated settings should have a
smooth upgrade process and get deprecation warnings until they adopt
the new settings.

Change-Id: Ideefb4d824cbd5b4b83f9eb773a75e536e3458fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/25/163825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: describe "with custom keystone identity_uri" do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } end before do params.merge!({ :keystone_identity_uri => 'https://foo.bar:1234/', }) end it 'configures identity_uri' do should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/identity_uri').with_value("https://foo.bar:1234/"); # since only auth_uri is set the deprecated auth parameters should # still get set in case they are still in use should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_host').with_value('127.0.0.1'); should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_port').with_value('35357'); should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_protocol').with_value('http'); end end describe "with custom keystone identity_uri and auth_uri" do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } end before do params.merge!({ :keystone_identity_uri => 'https://foo.bar:35357/', :keystone_auth_uri => 'https://foo.bar:5000/v2.0/', }) end it 'configures identity_uri and auth_uri but deprecates old auth settings' do should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/identity_uri').with_value("https://foo.bar:35357/"); should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_uri').with_value("https://foo.bar:5000/v2.0/"); should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_admin_prefix').with(:ensure => 'absent') should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_port').with(:ensure => 'absent') should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_protocol').with(:ensure => 'absent') should contain_ceilometer_config('keystone_authtoken/auth_host').with(:ensure => 'absent') end end

subject: Manila cDOT driver should use loopingcall for ASUP report timing
revisions:

commit_message:
Manila cDOT driver should use loopingcall for ASUP report timing

The Manila cDOT driver uses its own timing code called from
get_share_stats() to do ASUP logging.  The periodic ASUP task
should instead be controlled by an independent loopingcall task.
This simplifies the driver and better separates code paths that
are unrelated and should run separately.

Change-Id: Ia3deda9415ecb2c026d4e91d047c8611b8432674
Closes-Bug: #1429972

commit_message:
Don't add exception instance in LOG.exception

LOG.exception will print out the full stacktrace, that's enough.
We should only record meaningful message.

Change-Id: I8b5c581717e6b78c11c46e226463927450c9f287

commit_message:
Add networking-bagpipe-l2 project

This stackforge project will host an ML2 mechanism driver relying on
bagpipe-bgp to implement Neutron networks with E-VPN.

Note that this patch intentionally adds a group 'bagpipe-l2' to
gerrit/projects.yaml, to map to the launchpad group at
https://launchpad.net/bagpipe-l2 .

Change-Id: Ib85f6247ae9ea2e29febe6cf39e7c2f224216159

subject: Fix infinite recursion caused by unnecessary stub
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-11 21:16:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/97b43595216e8feeb8fe785c7e16a4d8a9dd6345', 'message': "Fix infinite recursion caused by unnecessary stub

The auth tests used a stub to alter `nova.RequestContext` to become
`FakeRequestContext`. The problem with this is that `FakeRequestContext`
inherits from `nova.RequestContext` which has the effect of making
`FakeRequestContext` point to itself for it's parent class.

This leads to infinite recursion if a context object is created after this
stub is set.

This code has worked up until now because no tests have created a new context
after this stub was set. Downstream patches, however, may end up creating a
context here, so we should fix this.

It turns out that this stub isn't necessary, so deleting it entirely is
sufficient to fix the issue and keep tests passing.

Closes-Bug: 1431022

Change-Id: I6969dc2759ff2dbb78de831dbd40ea24cc3840ad
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-11 22:01:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dc62ace981f615834dc383092bacbac89c663f73', 'message': "Fix infinite recursion caused by unnecessary stub

commit_message:
Fix infinite recursion caused by unnecessary stub

The auth tests used a stub to alter `nova.RequestContext` to become
`FakeRequestContext`. The problem with this is that `FakeRequestContext`
inherits from `nova.RequestContext` which has the effect of making
`FakeRequestContext` point to itself for it's parent class.

This leads to infinite recursion if a context object is created after this
stub is set.

This code has worked up until now because no tests have created a new context
after this stub was set. Downstream patches, however, may end up creating a
context here, so we should fix this.

It turns out that this stub isn't necessary, so deleting it entirely is
sufficient to fix the issue and keep tests passing.

Closes-Bug: 1431022

Change-Id: I6969dc2759ff2dbb78de831dbd40ea24cc3840ad

commit_message:
Improve 'attach interface' exception handling

Previously, if a user attempted to launch an instance and specified a
port that belonged to a different tenant, a HTTP 500 Server
Error was returned to the user. This patch changes that to a
more informative HTTPBadRequest exception.

Change-Id: I4a4017407ac7358490974cbffc5b7dbb7a200f44
Closes-bug: #1409617
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/146788/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if port_id: # Check if port belongs to the tenant for the instance. port_info = self.network_api.show_port(context, port_id) if port_info['port']['tenant_id'] != instance.project_id: msg_dict = {'port': port_id, 'instance': server_id, 'tenant': instance.project_id} msg = _("Port: %(port)s is not allowed to attach " "to instance: %(instance)s, since it doesn't " "belong to tenant: %(tenant)s.") % msg_dict raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) except exception.Forbidden as e: raise exc.HTTPForbidden(explanation=e.format_message())

commit_message:
Create DesignateAdapter and surrounding infrastructure

This implements the basic infrastructure for DesignateAdapter
and creates the basis for the API v2/v1 Adapter objects

These will replace views in both the v1 and v2 APIs, and allow for the
validation of API requests to move into the DesignateObjects themselves.

Example use is

   zone = central.get_domain(blah)
   DesignateAdapter.render('API_v1', zone)
   // Returns v1 dict, ready to	convert to JSON

These objects have a registry of sorts, so all calls will be made to
DesignateAdapter, and the combination of the format param ('API_v1' in
this case) will load the right Adapter and return the right JSON ready
dict.

Change-Id: I2b77205751675de600248180fafbfe22a2c1d8f5
Blueprint: validation-cleanup

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import six from designate import objects from designate import exceptions LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class DesignateObjectAdapterMetaclass(type): def __init__(cls, names, bases, dict_): if not hasattr(cls, '_adapter_classes'): cls._adapter_classes = {} return key = '%s:%s' % (cls.adapter_format(), cls.adapter_object()) if key not in cls._adapter_classes: cls._adapter_classes[key] = cls else: raise Exception( "Duplicate DesignateAdapterObject with" " format '%(format)s and object %(object)s'" % {'format': cls.adapter_format(), 'object': cls.adapter_object()} ) @six.add_metaclass(DesignateObjectAdapterMetaclass) class DesignateAdapter(object): """docstring for DesignateObjectAdapter""" ADAPTER_OBJECT = objects.DesignateObject @classmethod def adapter_format(cls): return cls.ADAPTER_FORMAT @classmethod def adapter_object(cls): return cls.ADAPTER_OBJECT.obj_name() @classmethod def get_object_adapter(cls, format_, object): key = '%s:%s' % (format_, object) return cls._adapter_classes[key] ##################### # Rendering methods # ##################### @classmethod def render(cls, format_, object, *args, **kwargs): if isinstance(object, objects.ListObjectMixin): # type_ = 'list' return cls.get_object_adapter( format_, object.obj_name())._render_list(object, *args, **kwargs) else: # type_ = 'object' return cls.get_object_adapter( format_, object.obj_name())._render_object(object, *args, **kwargs) @classmethod def _render_inner_object(cls, object, *args, **kwargs): # The dict we will return to be rendered to JSON / output format r_obj = {} # Loop over all fields that are supposed to be output for key, value in cls.MODIFICATIONS['fields'].iteritems(): # Get properties for this field field_props = cls.MODIFICATIONS['fields'][key] # Check if it has to be renamed if field_props.get('rename', False): obj = getattr(object, field_props.get('rename')) # if rename is specified we need to change the key obj_key = field_props.get('rename') else: # if not, move on obj = getattr(object, key, None) obj_key = key # Check if this item is a relation (another DesignateObject that # will need to be converted itself if object.FIELDS.get(obj_key, {}).get('relation'): # Get a adapter for the nested object # Get the class the object is and get its adapter, then set # the item in the dict to the output r_obj[key] = cls.get_object_adapter( cls.ADAPTER_FORMAT, object.FIELDS[obj_key].get('relation_cls')).render( obj, *args, **kwargs) else: # Just attach the damn item if there is no weird edge cases r_obj[key] = obj # Send it back return r_obj @classmethod def _render_inner_list(cls, list_object, *args, **kwargs): # The list we will return to be rendered to JSON / output format r_list = [] # iterate and convert each DesignateObject in the list, and append to # the object we are returning for object in list_object: r_list.append(cls.get_object_adapter( cls.ADAPTER_FORMAT, object.obj_name()).render(object, *args, **kwargs)) return r_list ##################### # Parsing methods # ##################### @classmethod def parse(cls, format_, values, output_object, *args, **kwargs): if isinstance(output_object, objects.ListObjectMixin): # type_ = 'list' return cls.get_object_adapter( format_, output_object.obj_name())._parse_list( values, output_object, *args, **kwargs) else: # type_ = 'object' return cls.get_object_adapter( format_, output_object.obj_name())._parse_object( values, output_object, *args, **kwargs) @classmethod def _parse_inner_object(cls, values, output_object, *args, **kwargs): error_keys = [] for key, value in values.iteritems(): error_flag = True if key in cls.MODIFICATIONS['fields']: # No rename needed obj_key = key error_flag = False # This item may need to be translated if cls.MODIFICATIONS['fields'][key].get('rename', False): obj_key = cls.MODIFICATIONS['fields'][key].get('rename') # Check if the key is a nested object if output_object.FIELDS.get(obj_key, {}).get('relation', False): # Get the right class name obj_class_name = output_object.FIELDS.get( obj_key, {}).get('relation_cls') # Get the an instance of it obj_class = \ objects.DesignateObject.obj_cls_from_name(obj_class_name) # Get the adapted object obj = \ cls.get_object_adapter( cls.ADAPTER_FORMAT, obj_class_name).parse( value, obj_class) # Set the object on the main object setattr(output_object, obj_key, obj) else: # No nested objects here, just set the value setattr(output_object, obj_key, value) if error_flag: # We got an extra key error_keys.append(key) if error_keys: error_message = str.format( 'Provided object does not match schema. Keys {0} are not ' 'valid in the request body', error_keys) raise exceptions.InvalidObject(error_message) return output_object @classmethod def _parse_inner_list(cls, values, output_object, *args, **kwargs): raise exceptions.NotImplemented('List adaption not implemented')

commit_message:
EMC Isilon Manila driver

The Isilon Manila driver supports the following functionalities:
* Create/delete NFS/CIFS share
* Create/delete snapshot
* Allow/deny access to share
* Create share from snapshot

implements: blueprint emc-isilon-manila-driver

Change-Id: If5f064751120890afba0571bc2b407d141ba0323
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/23/155023/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 EMC # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Isilon specific NAS backend plugin. """ import logging import os import requests import manila.exception from manila.share.drivers.emc.plugins.base import StorageConnection from manila.share.drivers.emc.plugins.isilon.isilon_api import IsilonApi logging.basicConfig() LOG = logging.getLogger('EmcIsilonManilaDriver') LOG.setLevel(logging.ERROR) class IsilonStorageConnection(StorageConnection): """Implements Isilon specific functionality for EMC Manila driver.""" def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(IsilonStorageConnection, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._server = None self._port = None self._username = None self._password = None self._auth = None self._server_url = None self._connect_resp = None self._root_dir = None self._verify_ssl_cert = None self._containers = {} self._shares = {} self._snapshots = {} self._isilon_api = None self._isilon_api_class = IsilonApi self.driver_handles_share_servers = False @staticmethod def _get_snapshot_path(snapshot_name, share_name): """Return path to a snapshot.""" return "/ifs/.snapshot/" + snapshot_name + "/" + share_name + "/" def _get_container_path(self, share): """Return path to a container.""" return os.path.join(self._root_dir, share['name']) def _copy_directory(self, source_path, target_path): """Copies the contents of one directory to another.""" headers = {"x-isi-ifs-copy-source": "/namespace" + source_path} resp = requests.put(self._server_url + "/namespace" + target_path, headers=headers, auth=self._auth, verify=self._verify_ssl_cert) resp.raise_for_status() def create_share(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, share_server): """Is called to create share.""" if share['share_proto'].startswith('NFS'): location = self._create_nfs_share(context, share, share_server) elif share['share_proto'].startswith('CIFS'): location = self._create_cifs_share(share) else: raise manila.exception.InvalidShare( reason='Unsupported share type') return location def create_share_from_snapshot(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, snapshot, share_server): """Creates a share from the snapshot.""" # create share at new location self.create_share(emc_share_driver, context, share, share_server) # clone snapshot to new location fq_target_dir = self._get_container_path(share) self._isilon_api.clone_snapshot(snapshot['name'], fq_target_dir) def _create_nfs_share(self, context, share, share_server): """Is called to create nfs share.""" container_path = self._get_container_path(share) self._isilon_api.create_directory(container_path) share_created = self._isilon_api.create_nfs_export(container_path) if not share_created: raise manila.exception.Error location = '%s:%s' % (self._server, container_path) return location def _create_cifs_share(self, share): """Is called to create cifs share.""" # create the directory container_path = self._get_container_path(share) self._isilon_api.create_directory(container_path) self._isilon_api.create_smb_share(share['name'], container_path) share_path = '//%s/%s' % (self._server, share['name']) return share_path def create_snapshot(self, emc_share_driver, context, snapshot, share_server): """Is called to create snapshot.""" snapshot_path = os.path.join(self._root_dir, snapshot['share_name']) self._isilon_api.create_snapshot(snapshot['name'], snapshot_path) def delete_share(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, share_server): """Is called to remove share.""" if share['share_proto'].startswith('NFS'): self._delete_nfs_share(share) elif share['share_proto'].startswith('CIFS'): self._delete_cifs_share(share) else: raise manila.exception.InvalidShare( reason='Unsupported share type') def _delete_nfs_share(self, share): """Is called to remove nfs share.""" share_id = self._isilon_api.lookup_nfs_export( self._root_dir + '/' + share['name']) export_deleted = self._isilon_api.delete_nfs_share(share_id) if not export_deleted: raise manila.exception.Error def _delete_cifs_share(self, share): """Is called to remove cifs share.""" self._isilon_api.delete_smb_share(share['name']) def delete_snapshot(self, emc_share_driver, context, snapshot, share_server): """Is called to remove snapshot.""" self._isilon_api.delete_snapshot(snapshot['name']) def ensure_share(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, share_server): """Invoked to sure that share is exported.""" try: if share['share_proto'].startswith('NFS'): export_path = self._get_container_path(share) export = self._isilon_api.lookup_nfs_export(export_path) if export is None: raise manila.exception.Error elif share['share_proto'].startswith('CIFS'): share = self._isilon_api.lookup_smb_share(share['name']) if share is None: raise manila.exception.Error else: raise manila.exception.InvalidShare( reason='Unsupported share type') except manila.exception.Error: self.create_share(emc_share_driver, context, share) def allow_access(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, access, share_server): """Allow access to the share.""" if share['share_proto'].startswith('NFS'): self._nfs_allow_access(share, access) elif share['share_proto'].startswith('CIFS'): self._cifs_allow_access(share, access) else: raise manila.exception.InvalidShare( reason='Unsupported share type') def _nfs_allow_access(self, share, access): """Allow access to nfs share.""" if access['access_type'] != 'ip': raise manila.exception.Error(('Invalid access type supplied. ' 'Only \'ip\' type is supported')) ips = access['access_to'] export_path = self._get_container_path(share) share_id = self._isilon_api.lookup_nfs_export(export_path) # get current allowed clients export = self._isilon_api.get_nfs_export(share_id) current_clients = export['clients'] # XY # format of ips could be '10.0.0.2', or '10.0q.0.2, 10.0.0.0/24' ips = ips.split(',') ips.extend(current_clients) export_params = {"clients": ips} url = self._server_url + "/platform/1/protocols/nfs/exports/" + str( share_id) resp = self._isilon_api.request('PUT', url, data=export_params) resp.raise_for_status() def _cifs_allow_access(self, share, access): """Allow access to cifs share.""" if access['access_type'] != 'ip': raise manila.exception.Error(('Invalid access type supplied. ' 'Only \'ip\' type is supported')) allowed_ip = 'allow:' + access['access_to'] smb_share = self._isilon_api.lookup_smb_share(share['name']) host_acl = smb_share['host_acl'] if allowed_ip not in host_acl: host_acl.append(allowed_ip) data = {'host_acl': host_acl} url = self._server_url + "/platform/1/protocols/smb/shares/" + \ smb_share['name'] r = self._isilon_api.request('PUT', url, data=data) r.raise_for_status() def deny_access(self, emc_share_driver, context, share, access, share_server): """Deny access to the share.""" if share['share_proto'].startswith('NFS'): self._nfs_deny_access(share, access) elif share['share_proto'].startswith('CIFS'): self._cifs_deny_access(share, access) else: raise manila.exception.InvalidShare( reason='Unsupported share type') def _nfs_deny_access(self, share, access): """Deny access to nfs share.""" if access['access_type'] != 'ip': raise manila.exception.Error(('Invalid access type supplied. ' 'Only \'ip\' type is supported')) denied_ip = access['access_to'] # get list of currently allowed client ips export_id = self._isilon_api.lookup_nfs_export( self._get_container_path(share)) if export_id is None: raise Exception clients = self._get_nfs_ip_access_list(export_id) allowed_ips = set(clients) if allowed_ips.__contains__(denied_ip): allowed_ips.remove(denied_ip) data = {"clients": list(allowed_ips)} url = self._server_url + "/platform/1/protocols/nfs/exports/" +\ str(export_id) r = self._isilon_api.request('PUT', url, data=data) r.raise_for_status() else: pass def _get_nfs_ip_access_list(self, export_id): export = self._isilon_api.get_nfs_export(export_id) if export is None: raise Exception return export["clients"] def _cifs_deny_access(self, share, access): """Deny access to cifs share.""" if access['access_type'] != 'ip': raise manila.exception.Error(('Invalid access type supplied. ' 'Only \'ip\' type is supported')) ip = access['access_to'] share_json = self._isilon_api.lookup_smb_share(share['name']) host_acl_list = share_json['host_acl'] allow_ip = 'allow:' + ip if allow_ip in host_acl_list: host_acl_list.remove(allow_ip) share_params = {"host_acl": host_acl_list} url = self._server_url + "/platform/1/protocols/smb/shares/" + \ share['name'] resp = self._isilon_api.request('PUT', url, data=share_params) resp.raise_for_status() else: pass def raise_connect_error(self, emc_share_driver): """Check for setup error.""" self._connect_resp.raise_for_status() def connect(self, emc_share_driver, context): """Connect to Isilon PAPI server.""" self._server = \ emc_share_driver.configuration.safe_get("emc_nas_server") self._port = \ int(emc_share_driver.configuration.safe_get("emc_nas_server_port")) self._server_url = 'https://' + self._server + ':' + str(self._port) self._username = \ emc_share_driver.configuration.safe_get("emc_nas_login") self._password = \ emc_share_driver.configuration.safe_get("emc_nas_password") self._auth = requests.auth.HTTPBasicAuth(self._username, self._password) self._root_dir = emc_share_driver.configuration.safe_get( "emc_isilon_share_root_dir") # TODO(IsilonDriver) - make verify ssl a config variable? self._verify_ssl_cert = False self._isilon_api = self._isilon_api_class(self._server_url, auth=( self._username, self._password), verify_ssl_cert=self._verify_ssl_cert) if self._isilon_api.is_path_existent(self._root_dir) is False: self._isilon_api.create_directory(self._root_dir, recursive=True) def update_share_status(self, stats_dict): """TODO.""" # TODO(IsilonDriver) # Perhaps query capacity, set storage_protocol, QoS support? pass def get_network_allocations_number(self): """Returns number of network allocations for creating VIFs.""" # TODO(IsilonDriver) return 0 def setup_server(self, network_info, metadata=None): """Set up and configures share server with given network parameters.""" # TODO(IsilonDriver) pass def teardown_server(self, server_details, security_services=None): """Teardown share server.""" # TODO(IsilonDriver) pass

commit_message:
Fix return code of irc_tests.py

The scripts was always returning 0 - see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/163876/1 which should have failed since
accessbot was not updated.

Fixed with properly wrapping main.

Change-Id: Ica8b4fa28cf9ac0009443340949ff6b32ccb9dd1

commit_message:
Language pack does not return source_uri during creation

After a language pack is created, the source uri is not displayed
by the CLI on create. Subsequent calls to show the language pack do.

Change-Id: Idc1f3f529fe8da4b99de743759ae1da3dc116596
Closes-bug: 1430927

added_lines: <para><xref linkend="archive-auto-extract"/> (bulk upload)</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>curl https://storage.example.com/info 2>/dev/null | python -m json.tool</userinput></screen> <para>This example shows a response body:</para> <programlisting language="json">{ "account_quotas": {}, "bulk_delete": { "max_deletes_per_request": 10000, "max_failed_deletes": 1000 }, "bulk_upload": { "max_containers_per_extraction": 10000, "max_failed_extractions": 1000 }, "container_quotas": {}, "crossdomain": {}, "ratelimit": {}, "slo": { "max_manifest_segments": 1000, "max_manifest_size": 2097152, "min_segment_size": 1 }, "staticweb": {}, "swift": { "account_listing_limit": 10000, "container_listing_limit": 10000, "max_account_name_length": 256, "max_container_name_length": 256, "max_file_size": 5368709122, "max_meta_count": 90, "max_meta_name_length": 128, "max_meta_value_length": 256, "max_object_name_length": 1024, "version": "1.11.0.90.g9ce7877" }, "tempauth": {}, "tempurl": { "methods": [ "GET", "HEAD", "PUT" ] } <para>The output shows that the Object Storage system has enabled the following features:</para> <para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Staticweb</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Temporary URL including allowed methods.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Bulk upload (Archive-auto-extract)</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Bulk delete</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Cross domain</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Account and container quota information</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> </para> <para> Additionally, the output shows the swift version and various constraints that have been applied to the Object Storage system. </para>

commit_message:
Add Information on Disabling Root Wrapper

Updating the Admin Guide and with the doc impact information from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/150904/: If root wrapper performance
becomes deficient or inadequate, this configuration disables root wrapper,
and adds a sudo only fallback.

Change-Id: Id583a03f02dd2730b87588e9f9defd19739f719c
backport: none
Closes-Bug: #1415747

commit_message:
Add ro level of access support to generic driver

Recently was added funtionality of rw/ro level of access to API.
Implement its support with NFS protocol for Generic driver and raise
error for CIFS protocol if it is not rw, because it does not allow
to handle both - ro and rw access rules for IPs/nets using one share export.

Implements BP generic-driver-ro-access

Change-Id: Iec7c01790bade6d4ce2f50b5a691e563dd756aa5

commit_message:
NetApp cDOT driver should not create useless export-policy rule

When using manila with a cDOT backend, the 'manila create' command
creates an export-policy for every newly created NFS share and adds
a policy rule with "localhost".  This is not necessary.

Change-Id: If4b54255328ed7384a195609d7e4e99c79d10638
Closes-Bug: #1427791

commit_message:
Add keystone docker-compose file.

To follow the model of container sets, net will be set to
host so that containers will not need to be linked together.

All enviroment variables will come from 'openstack.env'.

Co-authored-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ifdb0f146ff82c0fedb09255f6e1955ecdc435444
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/06/163906/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: keystone: image: kollaglue/centos-rdo-keystone name: keystone net: "host" env_file: - openstack.env

commit_message:
Allow port mac_address to be modified

Added a note on ability to modify port MAC address
 in the ML2 plugin to the Admin Guide.

Change-Id: Ic6a00b8198e57a37abb7d09944c8b74f07eaed8d
Closes-Bug: #1417683
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/66/161166/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <note> <para>Since Juno a port <option>mac-address</option> can be modified in the ML2 plug-in. That is required when NIC fails on ironic servers and is replaced with the new one which has a different mac address. The port should be updated with the new mac address, so the NIC can retain the same IP address.</para> </note>

commit_message:
Improve error handling in refactored Tgt driver

Only allow IOError to fall through when file not found is
acceptable. Cleanup a few error messages, remove uses of six as
this is not required

Closes-Bug: 1422095
Change-Id: I8a8f1ee561b15b38860b31cae1b444527e998869
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/13/154713/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except IOError as ErrorFileNotFound: LOG.debug('Failed to open config for %(vol_id)s: %(e)s', {'vol_id': vol_id, 'e': six.text_type(ErrorFileNotFound)}) # tgt is linux specific if ErrorFileNotFound.errno == 2: return None else: raise except Exception as ErrorVolumeException: LOG.debug('Failed to open config for %(vol_id)s: %(e)s', {'vol_id': vol_id, 'e': six.text_type(ErrorVolumeException)}) raise
deleted_lines: except Exception as e: LOG.debug('Failed to open config for %(vol_id)s: %(e)s' % {'vol_id': vol_id, 'e': six.text_type(e)}) return None

commit_message:
provisioning rabbitmq via userdata/cloud-init

- changed create cluster flows from a combination of unordered and
  linear flows to a graph flow
- added userdata generation step to create userdata to be used by
  each VM
- added check_or_restart_rabbitmq, to check rabbitmq status a
  number of times then restart the VM, before checking again

Change-Id: I98f2aa031ccd7e8bb068fa4cece3dd8af263e33e

added_lines: <para>The system documentation for an OpenStack cloud deployment should follow the templates and best practices for the Enterprise Information Technology System in your organization. Organizations often have compliance requirements which may require an overall System Security Plan to inventory and document the architecture of a given system. There are common challenges across the industry related to documenting the dynamic cloud infrastructure and keeping the information up-to-date.</para>

subject: Add oneshot cron trigger
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-19 12:16:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/075bb5e0bc4b59d13a8e817a43ab3c9bc3979a12', 'message': 'Add oneshot cron trigger

Add the possibility to launch oneshot cron triggers.
Those trigger are only executed once at a given date.

To use them you must specify a special pattern begining with an "@".
mistral cron-trigger-create test "@2015-02-11 16:18" reboot_server input.json

Once executed, instead of computing the next occurence, the trigger is deleted.

commit_message:
Add oneshot cron trigger

Add the possibility to launch oneshot cron triggers.
Those trigger are only executed once at a given date.

To use them you must specify a special pattern begining with an "@".
"@YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM"

Exemple:
mistral cron-trigger-create test "@2015-02-11 16:18" reboot_server input.json

Once executed, instead of computing the next occurence, the trigger is deleted.

Change-Id: I78f6c9d69fd610475c640074aa22c11a10f9c90f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/46/157346/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if t.pattern[0] == "@": db_api_v2.delete_cron_trigger(t.name) else: next_time = triggers.get_next_execution_time( t.pattern, t.next_execution_time ) db_api_v2.update_cron_trigger( t.name, {'next_execution_time': next_time} )
deleted_lines: next_time = triggers.get_next_execution_time( t.pattern, t.next_execution_time ) db_api_v2.update_cron_trigger( t.name, {'next_execution_time': next_time} )

commit_message:
Cleanup cinder common.ent

It appears on the cinder common.ent file was copied over from nova
and it contains numerous entities that are never used. This patch
set removes the entities that are not referenced.

Change-Id: Ida64ceba902b6e4490f06c92bfd481f91c9ad8e7

commit_message:
Add Client object to documentation

After wanting to do a rather simple thing -- figure out of the
"timeout" argument to nodepool was a int or a float, it lead me down
the rabbit-hole to python-novaclient.

It turns out the timeout does get passed through to requests as a
float so that mystery was solved.

But the "Client" class seems to be missing from the documentation as
it's not included in the class list.  So add that and also at least
document the types of the arguments.

However, then I noticd that this wasn't showing up; turns out sphinx
requires "autoclass_content = both" if you want it to document
__init__() functions.  Several other classes had their init args
documented but they weren't showing up because of this.

Change-Id: I8f44e92f2a0f25a75926b1813a8b374e79b4f5db

commit_message:
nova client cinder query param changed to display_name

nova client is not able to show the list of volumes when
querying by name.This is because cinder api accepts only
display_name as query parameter and when qeried with 'name'
parameter returns a empty list

Change-Id: Ie4ffc275d1754052d9e239d8457baf6f7fd53b83
Closes-Bug: #1430415

commit_message:
Remove potential extra work in IpRouteCommand

Variable device_list initialisation and usage is messed up in method
IpRouteCommand.pullup_route. This lead to multiple remove/add same
routes on interface. It's not affect final result, but it do extra work.

By the way, is someone know this method need for? Method's docsting tell
us "Ensures that the route entry for the interface is before all others
on the same subnet." But this is have no sense.

Records in routing table sorted according to destination netmask.  More
specific rules goes first. more common goes last. If someone really need
to change order of records in routing table he should use separate
routing table (See "man ip-route" for info about routing tables and
routing rules. Don't mess routing rules and routing records.)

Change-Id: I35ae4ab9e02a8036d5b823d972c200ce7eaf11c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/11/112311/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME(dbogun): when this can happen? records in routing table sorted according destination netmask length. If someone need change order of records in routing table he should use separate routing table (See man ip-route for info about routing tables and routing rules. Don't mess routing rules and routing records.) device_list = [] def execute(self, cmds, addl_env=None, check_exit_code=True): if addl_env is None: addl_env = dict()

subject: Eventlet green threads not released back to pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-02 06:35:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0fd940222a1a2a46e805e2355a2d20a900a7fd07', 'message': "Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection. Because of this problem, the green thread is not released
back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Added a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout
behaviour. Allows closing idle client connections after a period of time, eg:

$ time nc localhost 8776
real    1m0.063s

Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).
Added client_socket_timeout option (default=900).

SecurityImpact

Closes-Bug: #1361360
Change-Id: I3a361d6590d1800b85791f23ac1cdfd79815341b
(cherry picked from commit 8e7a0dbb12082f6159d98a4628fb8a6fcd05e95a)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-01-02 08:46:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c64466e392766145dfd360f1cc1821f034f03f29', 'message': "Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket

back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the

set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Added a parameter to take advantage of the new(ish) eventlet socket timeout

$ time nc localhost 8776

Setting 'client_socket_timeout = 0' means do not timeout.

DocImpact:

Closes-Bug: #1361360

(cherry picked from commit 8e7a0dbb12082f6159d98a4628fb8a6fcd05e95a)
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-03-10 22:21:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bdd50f01f4ac2d940fc55e68b419c4506be3d6b6', 'message': "Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection. Because of this problem, the green thread is not released
back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to

commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections. Hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection. Because of this problem, the green thread is not released
back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Icehouse backport note: socket_timeout was dropped, it was introduced
in 0.14[*] and Icehouse eventlet lower bound is 0.13

[*] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/7d4916f01462de09cb58853d9de2e85777c2ad5b

DocImpact:
Added wsgi_keep_alive option (default=True).

SecurityImpact

Closes-Bug: #1361360
Change-Id: I3a361d6590d1800b85791f23ac1cdfd79815341b
(cherry picked from commit 8e7a0dbb12082f6159d98a4628fb8a6fcd05e95a)

(integer # value) # client_socket_timeout = 900 # wsgi keepalive option. Determines if connections are allowed to be held open # by clients after a request is fulfilled. A value of False will ensure that # the socket connection will be explicitly closed once a response has been # sent to the client. # wsgi_keep_alive = True

commit_message:
Verify all quotas before updating the db

Update quota multi-value in one request is not an atomicity operation,
so even if a quota is invalid (Ex: ram less than already used), some values
may change but the return code is 400.

This patch will first check all the quotas before hitting the DB.

Change-Id: I22171c1f1f8171c502f2a9d710cfac38f5b38d85
Closes-Bug: #1291199
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/79904/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for key, value in quota_set.items(): if key in NON_QUOTA_KEYS or (not value and value != 0): continue

commit_message:
storage: add support for value research

This allow the driver to provide a method to search for a certain value.
That is useful to look for period where some metrics are over a certain
value, e.g. finding all metrics (and therefore resources) where the CPU
usage is above 80%.

Change-Id: I0fab7b80424371b1f4d213ce8aecefe353cce1a6

commit_message:
Adjust Cinder to support FCP on System z systems

There are some platform specific changes needed to allow Cinder to
support FCP on System z: the System z specific format of the device file
paths, adding and removing devices explicitely, and ignoring vHBAs which
are offline.

Partial-Implements blueprint linux-systemz

Change-Id: Ia61c37246235bec618de5bb7f718e8b5520bc9ae

added_lines: import platform if platform.machine() == 's390x': target_lun = "0x00%02d000000000000" % int(connection_properties.get('target_lun', 0)) host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/ccw-%s-zfcp-%s:%s" % (pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun)) LOG.debug("zKVM: pci_num=%s target_wwn=%s target_lun=%s" % (pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun)) self._linuxfc.configure_scsi_device(pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun) host_devices.append(host_device) else : host_device = ("/dev/disk/by-path/pci-%s-fc-%s-lun-%s" % (pci_num, target_wwn, connection_properties.get('target_lun', 0))) host_devices.append(host_device) if platform.machine() == 's390x': LOG.debug("zKVM: s390x platform") ports = connection_properties['target_wwn'] wwns = [] # we support a list of wwns or a single wwn if isinstance(ports, list): for wwn in ports: wwns.append(str(wwn)) elif isinstance(ports, basestring): wwns.append(str(ports)) hbas = self._linuxfc.get_fc_hbas_info() for hba in hbas: pci_num = self._get_pci_num(hba) LOG.debug("zKVM pci_num=%s " % pci_num) if pci_num is not None: for wwn in wwns: target_wwn = "0x%s" % wwn.lower() target_lun = "0x00%02d000000000000" % int(connection_properties.get('target_lun', 0)) LOG.debug("zKVM: pci_num=%s target_wwn=%s target_lun=%s" % (pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun)) self._linuxfc.deconfigure_scsi_device(pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun)

commit_message:
Starting to split out orders from test_resources.py

More progress toward spliting out test_resources.py and removing
our dependence on mocks.

Change-Id: Id28a7229cdd8964dea0d90ba34360c175aa3bcba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/41/162441/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: class WhenCreatingOrdersUsingOrdersResource(FunctionalTest): def setUp(self): super( WhenCreatingOrdersUsingOrdersResource, self ).setUp() self.app = webtest.TestApp(app.build_wsgi_app(self.root)) self.app.extra_environ = get_barbican_env(self.external_project_id) database_utils.setup_in_memory_db() self.addCleanup(database_utils.in_memory_cleanup) @property def root(self): self._init() class RootController(object): orders = controllers.orders.OrdersController(self.queue_resource) return RootController() def _init(self): self.secret_name = 'name' self.secret_payload_content_type = 'application/octet-stream' self.secret_algorithm = "aes" self.secret_bit_length = 128 self.secret_mode = "cbc" self.project_internal_id = 'projectid1234' self.external_project_id = 'keystoneid1234' self.project = models.Project() self.project.id = self.project_internal_id self.project.external_id = self.external_project_id self.project_repo = mock.MagicMock() self.project_repo.get.return_value = self.project self.order_repo = mock.MagicMock() self.order_repo.create_from.return_value = None self.setup_order_repository_mock(self.order_repo) self.setup_project_repository_mock(self.project_repo) self.queue_resource = mock.MagicMock() self.queue_resource.process_order.return_value = None self.type = 'key' self.meta = {"name": "secretname", "algorithm": "AES", "bit_length": 256, "mode": "cbc", 'payload_content_type': 'application/octet-stream'} self.key_order_req = {'type': self.type, 'meta': self.meta} def test_should_add_new_order(self): resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', self.key_order_req ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) self.queue_resource.process_type_order.assert_called_once_with( order_id=None, project_id=self.external_project_id) args, kwargs = self.order_repo.create_from.call_args order = args[0] self.assertIsInstance(order, models.Order) def test_should_fail_creating_order_with_bogus_content(self): resp = self.app.post( '/orders/', 'bogus', headers={ 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) def test_should_allow_add_new_order_unsupported_algorithm(self): # TODO(john-wood-w) Allow until plugin validation is added. # Using unsupported algorithm field for this test self.unsupported_req = { 'type': 'key', 'meta': { 'name': self.secret_name, 'payload_content_type': self.secret_payload_content_type, 'algorithm': "not supported", 'bit_length': self.secret_bit_length, 'mode': self.secret_mode } } resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', self.unsupported_req, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 202) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_no_secret_info(self): resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', {}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_no_type(self): resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', {'meta': self.meta}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_no_meta(self): resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', {'type': self.type}, expect_errors=True ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_bad_json(self): resp = self.app.post( '/orders/', '', expect_errors=True, headers={'Content-Type': 'application/json'}, ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_no_content_type_header(self): resp = self.app.post( '/orders/', self.key_order_req, expect_errors=True, ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 415) def test_should_raise_add_new_order_with_unsupported_content_type(self): self.meta["payload_content_type"] = 'unsupported type' resp = self.app.post_json( '/orders/', self.key_order_req, expect_errors=True, ) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400)

commit_message:
Add an additional config nova-network

Add an additional config nova-network, which overwrites the node name

Closes-bug: #1392719
Closes-bug: #1426040

Change-Id: If36aa82f325a05af31bfa0bda16686fa975e32a8
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/15/162915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $nova_network_config = '/etc/nova/nova.conf', $nova_network_config_dir = '/etc/nova/nova-network.d' $nova_network_config_ha = "${nova_network_config_dir}/nova-network-ha.conf" if ! defined(File[$nova_network_config_dir]) { file { $nova_network_config_dir: ensure => directory, owner => nova, group => nova, mode => '0750' } } if ! defined(File[$nova_network_config_ha]) { file { $nova_network_config_ha: ensure => present, content => template('vmware/nova-network-ha.conf.erb'), mode => '0600', owner => nova, group => nova, } } 'amqp_server_port' => $amqp_port, 'config' => $nova_network_config, 'additional_parameters' => "--config-file=${nova_network_config_ha}", File["${nova_network_config_dir}"]-> File["${nova_network_config_ha}"]->

commit_message:
update language bindings page

  - added missing projects (ironic, zaqar, sahara, barbican)
  - make service names consistent with openstack-projects.html

Change-Id: I0f816ffd382feaa28aa039953c1ad6c189f9b7e7

subject: Add CHAP support to PureISCSIDriver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-25 19:03:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f99442a8a2aac7c7fd97540297ae9638d4a98d1f', 'message': 'Add CHAP support to PureISCSIDriver

This change adds support for iSCSI CHAP with randomly generated
secrets for each initiator. Due to some restrictions with storing meta
data in the backend these secrets need to be stored someplace accessible
from the driver. We have opted for a file on the host running the cinder
service. The file is created with read/write for only the cinder user,
and will contain a mapping between initiators and their configured CHAP
information.

To make this work in a stable fashion and to prevent any lock-outs we
are working around some iSCSI issues surrounding disconnecting iSCSI
portals by always keeping a single anchor volume attached to a host
which will hold open prevent any connection errors and stop from having
the iSCSI connection from being closed.

Implements: blueprint pure-iscsi-chap-support
Change-Id: I5dfc29602a41ed565af074368947c99aafdc0ab8

commit_message:
Add CHAP support to PureISCSIDriver

This change adds support for iSCSI CHAP with randomly generated
secrets for each initiator. Due to some restrictions with storing meta
data in the backend these secrets need to be stored someplace accessible
from the driver. We will use the driver specific initiator data in the
Cinder DB to store them.

Implements: blueprint pure-iscsi-chap-support
Change-Id: I5dfc29602a41ed565af074368947c99aafdc0ab8
