commit_message:
Allow capabilities for scheduling from Nova

This spec talks about how capabilities may be
used from Nova for scheduling and how an operator
can configure nodes with capabilities.

NOTE: This spec is more of an agreement on how to
use capabilities for scheduling after the recent
patch merged in Nova (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/141012/).
This spec doesn't propose anything new.  The
actual work for a generic way for mentioning hardware
capabilities/driver capabilities has been bumped to L
and will be looked on in the next release.

Change-Id: I256d286e93fa2256b94af6d884f884cba4a51379
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/43/158243/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Handling capabilities passed from Nova in Ironic ================================================ Ironic needs to handle the user-requested capabilities in Nova. This spec talks about how an operator can configure the capabilities to be used in Ironic (for Kilo) and how it can made use of in Nova with flavors. This patch is more of a proposal of how to make use of the capabilities for node scheduling for Kilo. NOTE: Haven't filed a blueprint for this spec yet as I am not sure about the complete fate of this proposal. Will file a blueprint later. Problem description =================== Nova can take user requested capabilities (in Nova flavor), look for compute nodes having those capabilities (in Nova scheduler) and provides that information to it's virt drivers. Recently the `Nova patch`_ for passing capabilities from Nova-Ironic virt driver to Ironic got merged. This spec talks about the changes in Ironic and how an operator can use them for scheduling purposes. .. _`Nova patch`: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/141012/ Proposed change =============== The first proposed change is to change the newly introduced ``boot_option`` in Ironic. Currently ``boot_option`` is a boolean can have just two values - ``netboot`` or ``localboot``. ``netboot`` is the default value. When scheduling from Nova, using ``localboot=true`` might seem better than providing ``boot_option=local``. Hereafter in the spec, ``boot_option=local`` is referred to as ``localboot=true``. There are two kinds of capabilities in Ironic right now: #. Hardware Capabilities - These are populated in Ironic by introspection or can be filled by operator manually in Node's properties in Ironic database. These capabilities are just for scheduling purposes only and Ironic doesn't take any action on them. Some examples include 'iLO Firmware version', 'Server Name/Model', etc. The workflow of using them for scheduling goes like this: * These may be populated either by introspection or manually. If operator populates them manually, it can be done with ironic node-update command-line:: ironic node-update <> replace properties/capabilities="foo:true" * This is polled by Ironic virt driver in Nova and then it is passed to Nova scheduler. * The user may request a node having a particular feature or a particular server model using Nova flavor:: nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:foo="true" If introspection populates some hardware properties, then it can be used with any of the supported operators in Nova:: nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:model="<in> Proliant" nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:nic_cap_gbps=">= 10" * Once a nova boot request comes with the above flavor, Nova scheduler matches nodes with the mentioned capabilities and then Ironic virt driver passes them down to Node's instance_info. * Ironic doesn't need to take any action on them. This is because Nova scheduler has already made sure that the selected node supports them. Keeping this information in Ironic node's instance_info is harmless for now. #. Driver Capabilities - These are capabilities that can be passed to Ironic in Node's instance_info (for example localboot, secure_boot (proposed and approved), boot_mode). These are capabilities that Ironic will need to take some action to prepare the node to be deployed with the requested capability. The workflow of using them for scheduling goes like this: * Some of capabilities of the driver needs to be populated manually by the operator. For example, to enable a node to be capable of performing localboot, operator may do:: ironic node-update <> replace properties/capabilities="localboot:true" For iLO driver, ``secure_boot`` will be populated by introspection. * This is polled by Ironic virt driver in Nova and then it is passed to Nova scheduler. * The user may request a node having a particular feature or a particular server model using Nova flavor:: nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:localboot="true" nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:secure_boot="true" For localboot feature, the user may pass in localboot as ``true`` for getting a node that boots locally. If the user wants a node that boots from network, they may not provide any extra properties. Same is true for ``secure_boot`` as well. If the user wishes a node with secure boot, then they may pass ``secure_boot`` as ``true``. Otherwise ``secure_boot`` will be disabled for the node. * For ``boot_mode``, the behaviour will be same as Juno. Drivers will be continue to read from ``properties/capabilties`` as they are the same information passed down in ``instance_info/capabilities``. Validation of the capabilties passed to Ironic might be required for now because of the following: #. For hardware capabilities, Nova scheduler does a match (direct match or with operators such as ``<in>``) and needn't be validated again. Ironic can just ignore them. #. For the capabiltities that Ironic takes action (for now these are ``boot_mode``, ``localboot`` and ``secure_boot`` (proposed and approved), there is a chance that user might use operators to get them matched. For example, ``boot_mode=uefi`` may be matched by:: nova flavor-key baremetal-flavor set capabilities:boot_mode="<in> b" NOTE: <in> stands for sub-string match. In such a case, Nova scheduler will match a node but will pass the capability in Node's instance_info as:: { 'capabilities': { 'boot_mode': '<in> b' } } However after patching instance_info, calling ``node-validate`` will fail and hence ``spawn`` in Ironic virt driver will fail reporting the error back to the user. Alternatives ------------ * We can refrain from changing ``boot_option`` to ``localboot`` so that more options for booting may be introduced later. But we don't know of any such options right now. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. RPC API impact -------------- None. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ None. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Users can make use flavors from Nova to select nodes with specific capabilities. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will need to add ``localboot`` as a capability as mentioned above inorder to make the node capable of booting locally. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- rameshg87 Work Items ---------- * Change ``boot_option`` to ``localboot``. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= None. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== The usage of capabilties for scheduling purpose will need to be documented. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Fixes element-info -d ubuntu errors

This patch adds the default elements path in the $ELEMENTS_PATH
environment variable. It also appends the default $ELEMENTS_PATH
if user had exported the $ELEMENTS_PATH in the enviroment.

Change-Id: Ic9da7c2d87aa13c6cf110a94ca521c8f6a1b0208
Closes-bug: #1265650
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/80/111980/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """ Added logic to add the default ELEMENTS_PATH in the system environment variable. This checks if $ELEMENTS_PATH environment variable is empty or not. If the $ELEMENTS_PATH is empty then it adds the native element path in the environment variable else it will append in it. """ native_ele_path = os.path.realpath(__file__) native_ele_path = native_ele_path.split("diskimage_builder")[0] native_ele_path += 'elements' runtime_ele_path = "/bin/../elements" if not os.environ.get('ELEMENTS_PATH'): os.environ['ELEMENTS_PATH'] = native_ele_path elif native_ele_path not in os.environ['ELEMENTS_PATH'] and \ runtime_ele_path not in os.environ['ELEMENTS_PATH']: os.environ['ELEMENTS_PATH'] += ":" + native_ele_path
deleted_lines: if not os.environ.get('ELEMENTS_PATH'): raise Exception("$ELEMENTS_PATH must be set.")

subject: Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-24 10:23:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/43dc70b2cf8a819039b2ca98a4a8136e050c6190', 'message': "Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service

Filter scheduler relies on volume services to report their stats in
order to make decisions - this nature makes scheduler service a bit
special when it starts because it can't really do anything without
knowning stats of avilable volume backend.  So the original
implementation of Filter Scheduler added a hook in init_host() to
ask all volume services to send their stats immediately (volume RPC
call 'publish_service_capabitlies()'), this reduced the chance of a
new volume being set to 'error' state becuase scheduler has no
knowledge of backends to minimum.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | RPC init                          |
              | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |     <-------------  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)

However, commit 65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419 moved
init_host() ahead of service RPC initialization because for volume
services, service initialization should be done before the service
starts accepting RPC requests.  This change unfortunately invalided
scheduler service's init_host() because that needs to be done *AFTER*
RPC is ready (a queue is bound to scheduler fanout exchange).  The
result is scheduler asks vol service to send update, but it misses
the information it asked for because the its queue hasn't been
created and bound to the fanout queue yet.  So scheduler always has
to wait for the next update from volume services to be able to work
properly.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |   (vol stats lost)  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)
              | RPC init                          |

This change add a new hook to Manager class called init_hook_with_rpc()
to allow services like scheduler to do something once RPC is ready.
This should restore scheduler's behavior before commit
65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419.

Change-Id: If6cf9030eb44c39a06ec501ac5c049d460782481
Closes-bug: #1409012
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-24 14:49:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/8338a3a43ee10e3c65e43c03ee9fa5fb77a551e2', 'message': "Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service

Filter scheduler relies on volume services to report their stats in
order to make decisions - this nature makes scheduler service a bit
special when it starts because it can't really do anything without
knowning stats of avilable volume backend.  So the original
implementation of Filter Scheduler added a hook in init_host() to
ask all volume services to send their stats immediately (volume RPC
call 'publish_service_capabitlies()'), this reduced the chance of a
new volume being set to 'error' state becuase scheduler has no
knowledge of backends to minimum.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | RPC init                          |
              | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |     <-------------  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)

However, commit 65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419 moved
init_host() ahead of service RPC initialization because for volume
services, service initialization should be done before the service
starts accepting RPC requests.  This change unfortunately invalided
scheduler service's init_host() because that needs to be done *AFTER*
RPC is ready (a queue is bound to scheduler fanout exchange).  The
result is scheduler asks vol service to send update, but it misses
the information it asked for because the its queue hasn't been
created and bound to the fanout queue yet.  So scheduler always has
to wait for the next update from volume services to be able to work
properly.

This should restore scheduler's behavior before commit

commit_message:
Allow scheduler to receive volume stats when starting service

Filter scheduler relies on volume services to report their stats in
order to make decisions - this nature makes scheduler service a bit
special when it starts because it can't really do anything without
knowning stats of avilable volume backend.  So the original
implementation of Filter Scheduler added a hook in init_host() to
ask all volume services to send their stats immediately (volume RPC
call 'publish_service_capabitlies()'), this reduced the chance of a
new volume being set to 'error' state because scheduler has no
knowledge of backends to minimum.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | RPC init                          |
              | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |     <-------------  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)

However, commit 65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419 moved
init_host() ahead of service RPC initialization because for volume
services, service initialization should be done before the service
starts accepting RPC requests.  This change unfortunately invalidated
scheduler service's init_host() because that needs to be done *AFTER*
RPC is ready (a queue is bound to scheduler fanout exchange).  The
result is scheduler asks vol service to send update, but it misses
the information it asked for because its queue hasn't been created
and bound to the fanout queue yet.  So scheduler always has to wait
for the next update from volume services to be able to work properly.

             Scheduler       RPC Exchanges    Volume Service(s)
service start | init_host()                       |
              | --pub_src_caps()-->|  ----------> | (vol fanout)
              |   (vol stats lost)  |<-vol stats--| (sch fanout)
              | RPC init                          |

This change adds a new hook to Manager class called init_hook_with_rpc()
to allow services like scheduler to do something once RPC is ready.
This should restore scheduler's behavior before commit
65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419.

Change-Id: If6cf9030eb44c39a06ec501ac5c049d460782481
Partial-bug: #1409012

commit_message:
adopt namespace-less oslo imports

oslo.config is now deprecated, so switching from oslo.config to right
package oslo_config. similarly oslo.serialization also deprecated, it
is also switched to oslo_serialization from oslo.serialization.

Change-Id: I54d226d702782c83cd18e2ef25e899346c0867ae
Closes-bug: #1416516

commit_message:
Interface must go prior to its subinterfaces

Each interface should go prior to its subinterfaces in transformations section of network scheme.
So, appropriate ports ordering was added.
Also, add_port() function was fixed.

Closes-Bug: #1430738
Change-Id: I0c8d23b20e5e701cac0f620062fa09e3ff4c3186

commit_message:
Adjust method for trimming ansible output debug information

This patch adjusts the method introduced in
I98fb57a56c1b7ddd6558e265cf6e65b159a05123 to trim the debug information
from the ansible output.

This adjustment allows the output to come to the console immediately,
instead of piping to a file and doing the processing after the ansible
run is complete.

Change-Id: I515adcad34ef76b8ea47fe90bc6572fb3aec1d2c
Partial-bug: #1425482
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/75/163775/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bash $(dirname ${0})/run-playbooks.sh | awk "${strip_debug}"
deleted_lines: source $(dirname ${0})/run-playbooks.sh > ansible-logs.tmp awk "${strip_debug}" < ansible-logs.tmp rm -f ansible-logs.tmp

commit_message:
Removed ubuntu target images from ISO

We are not allowed to re-distribute
ubuntu packages as well as ubuntu images.
We are going to build ubuntu target images
just before we start actual provision process.

This patch removes ubuntu target images from ISO.

Change-Id: Ic1b320bd4becd9deef0aaf326f8f05957958ca1c
Implements: blueprint consume-external-ubuntu

commit_message:
Adding barbican client and keymgr module

This change implements the key manager abstraction module and barbican
client helper for the improved secret storage spec.

Changes
* adding barbican module
* adding keymgr module
* adding a session method to the keystone module
* adding tests for keymgr module
* adding documentation for keymgr usage

SecurityImpact

Implements: blueprint improved-secret-storage
Change-Id: I462f2f6cdc35470f75771b5beca10899a591b46a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/98/162198/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: External key manager usage -------------------------- Sahara generates and stores several passwords during the course of operation. To harden Sahara's usage of passwords it can be instructed to use an external key manager for storage and retrieval of these secrets. To enable this feature there must first be an OpenStack Key Manager service deployed within the stack. Currently, the Barbican project is the only key manager supported by Sahara. With a Key Manager service deployed on the stack, Sahara must be configured to enable the external storage of secrets. This is accomplished by editing the configuration file as follows: .. sourcecode:: cfg [DEFAULT] use_external_key_manager=True .. TODO (mimccune) this language should be removed once a new keystone authentication section has been created in the configuration file. Additionally, at this time there are two more values which must be provided to ensure proper access for Sahara to the Key Manager service. These are the Identity domain for the administrative user and the domain for the administrative project. By default these values will appear as: .. sourcecode:: cfg [DEFAULT] admin_user_domain_name=default admin_project_domain_name=default With all of these values configured and the Key Manager service deployed, Sahara will begin storing its secrets in the external manager.

commit_message:
Add config option to override url for versions

The versions url returns the wrong data when cinder api is behind
a proxy. This adds a new config option so it can be set properly.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I46a90120b21e43bf8dca9e5f0efdf339f0d3e8e6
Closes-Bug: #1384379

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_serialization import jsonutils import webob from cinder.api import versions from cinder import test class VersionsTest(test.TestCase): """Test the version information returned from the API service.""" def test_get_version_list_public_endpoint(self): req = webob.Request.blank('/', base_url='http://127.0.0.1:8776/') req.accept = 'application/json' self.override_config('public_endpoint', 'https://example.com:8776') res = versions.Versions().index(req) results = res['versions'] expected = [ { 'id': 'v1.0', 'status': 'SUPPORTED', 'updated': '2014-06-28T12:20:21Z', 'links': [{'rel': 'self', 'href': 'https://example.com:8776/v1/'}], }, { 'id': 'v2.0', 'status': 'CURRENT', 'updated': '2012-11-21T11:33:21Z', 'links': [{'rel': 'self', 'href': 'https://example.com:8776/v2/'}], }, ] self.assertEqual(expected, results)

Add entry point definitions

Add entry point definitions for the ovn ml2 mechanism driver and the
l3 service plugin.  This makes configuration to use these drivers
easier.

commit_message:
Define the behavior for a 405 response

This commit adds language to the API reference describing the behavior
of the service when a request is sent to a recognized API URI, but the
request does not use a supported HTTP method.

Change-Id: I31143ea0f7e6727b7f80f83dced10c68c44ffe1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/11/131411/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: General API information Authenticated calls which target a known resource (URI) but use an HTTP method not supported by the implementation return a 405 Method Not Allowed. The Allow header of the response indicates the HTTP methods which are supported for the resource.

commit_message:
rest: uses search query to filter on metric aggregation

This patches change the metric aggregation for resources so it uses a
dedicated endpoint that accepts the same kind of filtering than the
search queries. That allows for much powerful filtering on resources.

Change-Id: I05ab0b7dd5548ae39d061c46768618ea1455d1e0

deleted_lines: from gnocchi import rest # NOTE(sileht): This is a bit ugly, but this is a workaround for this # webob bug: # https://github.com/Pylons/webob/issues/164 if six.PY3: rest.LOGICAL_AND = '+' result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/server_group=" + server_group + urllib_parse.quote(rest.LOGICAL_AND) + "display_name=myinstance" + "/metric/foo/measures?aggregation=max", status=400) def test_get_res_named_metric_measure_aggregation_query_invalid(self): # NOTE(sileht): This is a bit ugly, but this is a workaround for this # webob bug: # https://github.com/Pylons/webob/issues/164 binary_kwargs = {} if six.PY3: rest.LOGICAL_AND = '+' binary_kwargs['encoding'] = 'utf-8' invalid_query = ("server_group" + urllib_parse.quote(rest.LOGICAL_AND) + "display_name=myinstance") result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/" + invalid_query + "/metric/foo/measures?aggregation=max", expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(400, result.status_code) self.assertIn(b'server_group' + six.binary_type(rest.LOGICAL_AND, **binary_kwargs) + b'display_name=myinstance', result.body) def test_get_res_named_metric_measure_aggregation_nominal(self): # NOTE(sileht): This is a bit ugly, but this is a workaround for this # webob bug: # https://github.com/Pylons/webob/issues/164 if six.PY3: rest.LOGICAL_AND = '+' result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/server_group=" + server_group + urllib_parse.quote(rest.LOGICAL_AND) + "display_name=myinstance" + "/metric/foo/measures?aggregation=max", expect_errors=True) result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/server_group=" + server_group + urllib_parse.quote(rest.LOGICAL_AND) + "display_name=myinstance" + "/metric/foo/measures?aggregation=min", expect_errors=True) result = self.app.get("/v1/resource/" + self.resource_type + "/server_group=notexistsyet" + "/metric/foo/measures?aggregation=min", expect_errors=True)

rest: change metric aggregation URL

This changes the metric aggregation URL as we are going to add an
endpoint to do aggregation over metric via resources in a subsequent
patch.

added_lines: What's New in Mirantis OpenStack 6.0.1 ====================================== Mirantis is pleased to make Mirantis OpenStack 6.0.1 available to our customers, partners and the community. New Features included in Mirantis OpenStack 6.0.1 ================================================= Support for the latest OpenStack Juno release --------------------------------------------- The OpenStack core projects in the Mirantis OpenStack hardened packages support the `OpenStack Juno 2014.2 <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ReleaseNotes/Juno>`_ release. Fuel 6.0.1 deploys this version of OpenStack on either CentOS or Ubuntu. .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/plugin-arch.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/100-node.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/ha-improve.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/fuel-upgrade.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/statistics.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/mcn.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/l3-multiple-agents.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/atop.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/glance-vmdk.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/vlan-for-vcenter.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/nsx.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/sahara-vcenter.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/ceilometer-vcenter.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/image-provision.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/mongodb-external.rst .. include:: /pages/release-notes/v6-0/new-features/openstack-update.rst Additional Information ---------------------- For information about Issues and Blueprints for Mirantis OpenStack 6.0.1, see the `Fuel for OpenStack 6.0.1 Milestone <https://launchpad.net/fuel/+milestone/6.0.1>`_ page.

commit_message:
Fix Incorrect parameters for Neutron Port APIs

1. Query parameters
   Add Query parameters for List API.
2. Read-only parameters for Binding Extension
   Remove vif_detail and vif_type from Request parameter for Add/Update APIs.
3. Details for xsd:dict parameter
   Add sub parameters of xsd:dict parameters such as allowed_address_pairs and extra_dhcp_opts.
4. device_id and device_owner
   Add device_id and device_owner for Create/Update APIs

Change-Id: I8baffc669d1e16260ae156d2718029cfb3513fb8
Closes-Bug: #1425783

commit_message:
Standardize REST API pagination params

The limit/marker API documentation is very inconsistent across projects and
this patch set standardizes it by:

* Creating a common_project.ent file that contains entities to be shared
  across multiple projects
* Adding the limit/marker param entities to the common file
* Updating the existing references to limit/marker to use the common file

This patch set also adds the missing limit/marker params to the appropriate
cinder docs.

Change-Id: Ic95d2d88cb5caa804fb45fc62b61665a97e4dde9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/02/161102/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Expect a response to a limited request to return between zero and limit items. commit_message:
Remove py33 env from default tox list

We no longer need to test on Python 3.3, so remove that environment from
the default list in the tox configuration.

Change-Id: Icb3f22224678f9dad5de610a40d43fbef47be7ef

commit_message:
Don't install nova's rootwrap file in light mode

Since we don't install Nova in light mode, /etc/nova/rootwrap.d/
doesn't exist, thus stack.sh would fail.

Change-Id: Iabb41422d8daae5a52d03957d099d187f7e1a0ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/88/163788/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo cp $ABSOLUTE_PATH/midonet_rootwrap.filters /etc/nova/rootwrap.d/

commit_message:
Refactoring installer kernel version defining

* Substituted including non-existents make file
  (which make builds in run time) with more obvious construction.
  Hope it makes this place more clear for those who is not an expert in
  GNU make. It is just for the sake of Fuel openness.

Change-Id: I50e8efdb44cdabd516a958de93b95b05f7e5687c
Closes-Bug: 1397259
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/73/137773/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/ubuntu/createchroot.done: $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/ubuntu/boot.done $(BUILD_DIR)/mirror/ubuntu/createchroot.done: export UBUNTU_INSTALLER_KERNEL_VERSION=$(strip $(patsubst lib/modules/%/kernel,%,$(shell zcat $(LOCAL_NETBOOT_DIR)/ubuntu-installer/amd64/initrd.gz | cpio --list 'lib/modules/*/kernel')))

subject: IBP: Added sleep 10 after node reboot
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-11 15:08:32.000000000', 'files': ['lib/astute/orchestrator.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute/commit/741f4af7861c18b694a21bff5fcbe0e407cb51a0', 'message': 'IBP: Added sleep 10 after node reboot

The reason for this fix to appear is that Cobbler runs reboot
command and reports reboot succeeded, but astute manages to get the type
of node OS via Mcollective (/etc/nailgun_systemtype) and runs node erasing
procedure for the nodes which type!=target. Erasing procedure in turn
kicks sysrq trigger which breaks the node.

Change-Id: I98cc29256fb9a807aba9b6dddc500864c74bd735
Closes-Bug: 1420256
'}]
commit_message:
IBP: Added sleep 10 after node reboot

The reason for this fix to appear is that Cobbler runs reboot
command and reports reboot succeeded, but astute manages to get the type
of node OS via Mcollective (/etc/nailgun_systemtype) and runs node erasing
procedure for the nodes which type!=target. Erasing procedure in turn
kicks sysrq trigger which breaks the node.

Change-Id: I98cc29256fb9a807aba9b6dddc500864c74bd735
Closes-Bug: 1420256
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/04/154904/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note: if the image based provisioning is used nodes are already # provisioned and rebooting is not necessary. In fact the forced # reboot can corrupt a node if it manages to reboot fast enough # (see LP #1394599) # XXX: actually there's a tiny probability to reboot a node being # provisioned in a traditional way (by Debian installer or anaconda), # however such a double reboot is not dangerous since cobbler will # boot such a node into installer once again. if provision_method == 'image' # We assume we have to give some time within reason # to make sure the node went offline before # watch_provision_progress tries to get its type and # then runs the erasing procedure which sends sysrq as well # (see LP #1420256) sleep 10 else
deleted_lines: # Note: if the image based provisioning is used nodes are already # provisioned and rebooting is not necessary. In fact the forced # reboot can corrupt a node if it manages to reboot fast enough # (see LP #1394599) # XXX: actually there's a tiny probability to reboot a node being # provisioned in a traditional way (by Debian installer or anaconda), # however such a double reboot is not dangerous since cobbler will # boot such a node into installer once again. if provision_method != 'image'

commit_message:
Add Digest intrinsic function

Digest intrinsic function takes an algorithm name (e.g. md5, sha512,
etc) and a string value and will resolve to the corresponding hash of
the value.

Usage:

    pwd_hash: { digest: ['sha512', { get_param: raw_password }] }

Implements: blueprint digest-intrinsic-function
Change-Id: I7b5332462013cf8063fadec1654fa9f364da45de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/88/137188/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_digest(self): snippet = {'digest': ['md5', 'foobar']} snippet_resolved = '3858f62230ac3c915f300c664312c63f' tmpl = parser.Template(hot_juno_tpl_empty) self.assertEqual(snippet_resolved, self.resolve(snippet, tmpl)) def test_digest_invalid_types(self): tmpl = parser.Template(hot_juno_tpl_empty) invalid_snippets = [ {'digest': 'invalid'}, {'digest': {'foo': 'invalid'}}, {'digest': [123]}, ] for snippet in invalid_snippets: exc = self.assertRaises(TypeError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('must be a list of strings', six.text_type(exc)) def test_digest_invalid_values(self): tmpl = parser.Template(hot_juno_tpl_empty) invalid_snippets = [ {'digest': []}, {'digest': ['foo']}, {'digest': ['foo', 'bar', 'baz']}, ] for snippet in invalid_snippets: exc = self.assertRaises(ValueError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('usage', six.text_type(exc)) def test_digest_invalid_algorithm(self): tmpl = parser.Template(hot_juno_tpl_empty) snippet = {'digest': ['invalid_algorithm', 'foobar']} exc = self.assertRaises(ValueError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('unsupported hash type', six.text_type(exc))

commit_message:
Ubuntu repos improvements

* description added to the Repositories setting
* all repo names are replaced by editable name fields
* added editable priority field to each repo
* headers added to the repo table

Change-Id: Ia4b661851446368b7b264044150ad8fd9d090d3b

commit_message:
Fix db migration script 057 failure on db2

Add a if condition before drop foreign key constraint.

Closes-Bug: #1431250
Change-Id: Idc3afeb8739a608ae618c605eb730a4eb3e3da84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/48/163748/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fkc_query = inspector.get_foreign_keys('resource_data') if fkc_query: fkc = ForeignKeyConstraint([rd_table.c.resource_id], [res_table.c.id], fkc_query[0]['name']) migrate_engine.execute(DropConstraint(fkc)) fkc_query = inspector.get_foreign_keys('resource_data') if fkc_query: fkc = ForeignKeyConstraint([rd_table.c.resource_id], [res_table.c.id], fkc_query[0]['name']) migrate_engine.execute(DropConstraint(fkc))
deleted_lines: fkc_name = inspector.get_foreign_keys('resource_data')[0]['name'] fkc = ForeignKeyConstraint([rd_table.c.resource_id], [res_table.c.id], fkc_name) migrate_engine.execute(DropConstraint(fkc)) fkc_name = inspector.get_foreign_keys('resource_data')[0]['name'] fkc = ForeignKeyConstraint([rd_table.c.resource_id], [res_table.c.id], fkc_name) migrate_engine.execute(DropConstraint(fkc))

commit_message:
Environment Template API documentation
Targets https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/environment-template

Change-Id: I58248e5843b66a94acad1efaa8124336a8c428c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/84/160284/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * **Environment-Template** The Environment template is the specification of a set of applications managed by a single tenant, which are related each other. The environment template is stored in a environment template catalogue, and it can be managed by the user (creation, deletion, updating...). Finally, it can be deployed on Openstack by translating into an environment. Environment Template API =============== +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | Attribute | Type | Description | +======================+============+===========================================+ | id | string | Unique ID | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | name | string | User-friendly name | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | created | datetime | Creation date and time in ISO format | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | updated | datetime | Modification date and time in ISO format | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | tenant_id | string | OpenStack tenant ID | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | version | int | Current version | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | networking | string | Network settings | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ | description | string | The environment template specification | +----------------------+------------+-------------------------------------------+ **Common response codes** +----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | Code | Description | +================+===========================================================+ | 200 | Operation completed successfully | +----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | 401 | User is not authorized to perform the operation | +----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ List Environments Templates --------------------------- *Request* +----------+----------------------------------+----------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+==================================+==================================+ | GET | /templates | Get a list of existing | | | | environment templates | +----------+----------------------------------+----------------------------------+ *Response* This call returns list of environment templates. Only the basic properties are returned. :: { "templates": [ { "updated": "2014-05-14T13:02:54", "networking": {}, "name": "test1", "created": "2014-05-14T13:02:46", "tenant_id": "726ed856965f43cc8e565bc991fa76c3", "version": 0, "id": "2fa5ab704749444bbeafe7991b412c33" }, { "updated": "2014-05-14T13:02:55", "networking": {}, "name": "test2", "created": "2014-05-14T13:02:51", "tenant_id": "726ed856965f43cc8e565bc991fa76c3", "version": 0, "id": "744e44812da84e858946f5d817de4f72" } ] } Create Environment Template --------------------------- +----------------------+------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ | Attribute | Type | Description | +======================+============+=========================================================+ | name | string | Environment template name; only alphanumeric characters | | | and '-' | | +----------------------+------------+---------------------------------------------------------+ *Request* +----------+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+================================+======================================+ | POST | /templates | Create a new environment template | +----------+--------------------------------+--------------------------------------+ * **Content-Type** application/json * **Example** {"name": "env_temp_name"} *Response* :: { "id": "ce373a477f211e187a55404a662f968", "name": "env_temp_name", "created": "2013-11-30T03:23:42Z", "updated": "2013-11-30T03:23:44Z", "tenant_id": "0849006f7ce94961b3aab4e46d6f229a", } Get Environment Details ----------------------- *Request* Return information about environment template itself and about applications, including to this environment template. +----------+--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+================================+=================================================+ | GET | /templates/{env-temp-id} | Obtains the enviroment template information | +----------+--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------+ * `env-temp-id` - environment template ID, required *Response* **Content-Type** application/json :: { "updated": "2015-01-26T09:12:51", "networking": { }, "name": "template_name", "created": "2015-01-26T09:12:51", "tenant_id": "00000000000000000000000000000001", "version": 0, "id": "aa9033ca7ce245fca10e38e1c8c4bbf7", } Delete Environment template --------------------------- *Request* +----------+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+===================================+===================================+ | DELETE | /templates/<env-temp-id> | Delete the template id | +----------+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+ *Parameters:* * `env-temp_id` - environment template ID, required Adding application to environment template ------------------------------------------ *Request* +----------+------------------------------------+----------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+====================================+==================================+ | POST | /templates/{env-temp-id}/services | Create a new application | +----------+------------------------------------+----------------------------------+ *Parameters:* * `env-temp-id` - The environment-template id, required * payload - the service description *Content-Type* application/json *Example* :: { "instance": { "assignFloatingIp": "true", "keyname": "mykeyname", "image": "cloud-fedora-v3", "flavor": "m1.medium", "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance", "id": "ef984a74-29a4-45c0-b1dc-2ab9f075732e" } }, "name": "orion", "port": "8080", "?": { "type": "io.murano.apps.apache.Tomcat", "id": "54cea43d-5970-4c73-b9ac-fea656f3c722" } } *Response* :: { "instance": { "assignFloatingIp": "true", "keyname": "mykeyname", "image": "cloud-fedora-v3", "flavor": "m1.medium", "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance", "id": "ef984a74-29a4-45c0-b1dc-2ab9f075732e" } }, "name": "orion", "?": { "type": "io.murano.apps.apache.Tomcat", "id": "54cea43d-5970-4c73-b9ac-fea656f3c722" }, "port": "8080" } Get applications information from an environment template --------------------------------------------------------- *Request* +----------+-------------------------------------+-----------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+====================================+====================================+ | GET | /templates/{env-temp-id}/services | It obtains the service description| +----------+-------------------------------------+-----------------------------------+ *Parameters:* * `env-temp-id` - The environment template ID, required *Content-Type* application/json *Response* :: [ { "instance": { "assignFloatingIp": "true", "keyname": "mykeyname", "image": "cloud-fedora-v3", "flavor": "m1.medium", "?": { "type": "io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance", "id": "ef984a74-29a4-45c0-b1dc-2ab9f075732e" } }, "name": "tomcat", "?": { "type": "io.murano.apps.apache.Tomcat", "id": "54cea43d-5970-4c73-b9ac-fea656f3c722" }, "port": "8080" }, { "instance": "ef984a74-29a4-45c0-b1dc-2ab9f075732e", "password": "XXX", "name": "mysql", "?": { "type": "io.murano.apps.database.MySQL", "id": "54cea43d-5970-4c73-b9ac-fea656f3c722" } } ] Create an environment from an environment template -------------------------------------------------- *Request* +----------+--------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Method | URI | Description | +==========+================================+==================================================+ | POST | /templates/{env-temp-id}/create-environment| Create an environment | +----------+--------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+ *Parameters:* * `env-temp-id` - The environment template ID, required *Payload:* * 'environment name': The environment name to be created. *Content-Type* application/json *Example* :: { 'name': 'environment_name' } *Response* :: { "environment_id": "aa90fadfafca10e38e1c8c4bbf7", "name": "environment_name", "created": "2015-01-26T09:12:51", "tenant_id": "00000000000000000000000000000001", "version": 0, "session_id": "adf4dadfaa9033ca7ce245fca10e38e1c8c4bbf7", }

Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>

commit_message:
Pass the gate for Icehouse

Add the config files to let pass the stackforge gates. Fix some PEP8

commit_message:
qpid: Always auto-delete queue of DirectConsumer

In case of the call()er die, the queue used to reply must be
automatically deleted, otherwise they will never been deleted.

This is done in the same way as the rabbit drivers does,
by enabling auto-delete on this queue.

Change-Id: Ib01981d704b8849e0115791ff90fbb74cbac421f
Closes-Bug: #1374519
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/41/124741/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Infer router instead of requiring it

* This change allows using our LB functionality through Horizon.
* It still requires that a router ID be given, however instead of
  requiring it from the user, it can be inferred from the subnet id by
  going through the neutron database.
* The limitations are:
  1) The subnet used by the Pool must be associated with a router.
  2) If an external subnet is used for the VIP, then the router
  associated with the pool's subnet must have its gateway set.

Fixes: MNP-25

This commit is backported from previous project
`python-neutron-plugin-midonet`:
https://github.com/midonet/python-neutron-plugin-midonet/commit/\
94e8378e423e4355ce35b782c15393889a909c87

Change-Id: I80837416b9944b2adb2e6b1b500f73d065a906c5

commit_message:
Separate /var/log from /var

Allocates 60/40 to /var and /var/log, respectively,
preventing incoming logs from saturating the disk
and impacting Docker container store.

commit_message:
1) When detecting flow sync issue, when a flow is reached to the
controller with no metadata start the bootstrap flow installation.
2) Create a bootstrap flow installation method
Closes-Bug: #1429600

Change-Id: Ia48729dcb892a071b5b0927bac758151f724ca72

commit_message:
Create ansible log file and directory

This commit adds the ansible log file to the aio bootstrap script
and creates a vanilla logging directory that will allow us to collect
additional information on what is happening within a given ansible run.

Partial-Bug: #1425482
Partial-Bug: #1428744
Change-Id: I2786f73334b99bfa98d344c50337c86f75fae273
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/90/161890/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Create ansible logging directory and add in a log file entry into ansible.cfg if [ -f "playbooks/ansible.cfg" ];then mkdir -p /openstack/log/ansible-logging sed -i '/\[defaults\]/a log_path = /openstack/log/ansible-logging/ansible.log' playbooks/ansible.cfg fi

commit_message:
Logic for handle vmware settings on nailgun

Vmware settings API support

Implements: blueprint vmware-ui-settings
Change-Id: If7ad968abc09c5f370d3ee52d5b14e6d48778fd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/23/161123/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class VmwareSettingsAction(SettingsAction): """Show or modify environment vmware settings """ action_name = "vmware-settings" def upload(self, params): """To upload vmware settings for some environment from some directory: fuel --env 1 vmware-settings --upload --dir path/to/directory """ env = Environment(params.env) vmware_settings_data = env.read_vmware_settings_data( directory=params.dir, serializer=self.serializer ) env.set_vmware_settings_data(vmware_settings_data) print("Vmware settings configuration uploaded.") def default(self, params): """To download default vmware settings for some environment in some directory: fuel --env 1 settings --default --dir path/to/directory """ env = Environment(params.env) vmware_default_data = env.get_default_vmware_settings_data() settings_file_path = env.write_vmware_settings_data( vmware_default_data, directory=params.dir, serializer=self.serializer) print( "Default vmware settings configuration downloaded to {0}." .format(settings_file_path) ) def download(self, params): """To download vmware settings for some environment in this directory: fuel --env 1 settings --download """ env = Environment(params.env) settings_data = env.get_vmware_settings_data() settings_file_path = env.write_vmware_settings_data( settings_data, directory=params.dir, serializer=self.serializer) print( "Vmware settings configuration for environment with id={0}" " downloaded to {1}" .format(env.id, settings_file_path) )

commit_message:
Removed debian-installer initrd and kernel

We are not allowed to re-distribute ubuntu debian-installer
kernel and initrd. So, we are going to download these files
from one of user defined ubuntu repos. We implemented this
as a pre-provision task which is supposed to run a shell
script.

This patch removes original ubuntu debian-installer
ramdisk and kernel and substitutes them with zero files just
to make sure cobbler is able to create corresponding Distro.

Change-Id: Ie154cfdf3c6e9b4f063ab859cd050be6faa1707e
Implements: blueprint consume-external-ubuntu
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/02/163602/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # As far as we are not allowed to re-distribute ubuntu # debian-installer kernel and initrd we are going to download # these files just before starting actual provisioning. # But we still need to be able to create ubuntu cobbler distro # which requires kernel and initrd to be available. So, we # just touch these files to work around cobbler's limitation. touch ${repodir}/ubuntu/x86_64/images/linux touch ${repodir}/ubuntu/x86_64/images/initrd.gz

commit_message:
Allow full v3 authentication

Allow authenticating with ids and fetching domain scoped tokens. Changes the
acceptable parameters to more specific parameter names so that _id and _name
parameters can no longer be confused.

This tries to not change the config file and existing credential loading paths.

Closes-Bug: #1420605
Change-Id: If5a889be5826d60bf61dbb84661a5896cb094875

Replace mox with mock for stack-delete test cases

This patch replace mox calls with equivalent mock calls for the stack
delete test cases.

commit_message:
Func test conf to specify boot config

This adds a functional test config option boot_config_env which
can specify a path to an environment file which defines boot config
resources for any test which needs the heat agent projects.

By default this value points to boot_config_none_env.yaml, which assumes
the image is already completely configured with the heat agent projects.

The aim is that in the gate jobs the following will be set:
boot_config_env=/opt/stack/new/heat-templates/hot/software-config/boot-config/test_image_env.yaml

And the image_ref will refer to the latest built image in
http://tarballs.openstack.org/heat-test-image/

Change-Id: I1fa09bf3a8be248829061b931dd773973732fa52

commit_message:
Add lockutils.get_lock_path() function

Provide an API to discover the path being used to store external lock
files. Tempest will use this to set up some additional locking and to
test its own behavior. Other projects might use it for error reporting
or other purposes.

Change-Id: Iad40c67072333cc25a6d3e39d7535ff14b573504
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.concurrency refs/changes/65/163565/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestGetLockPath(test_base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestGetLockPath, self).setUp() self.conf = self.useFixture(config.Config(lockutils.CONF)).conf def test_get_default(self): lockutils.set_defaults(lock_path='/the/path') self.assertEqual('/the/path', lockutils.get_lock_path(self.conf)) def test_get_override(self): lockutils._register_opts(self.conf) self.conf.set_override('lock_path', '/alternate/path', group='oslo_concurrency') self.assertEqual('/alternate/path', lockutils.get_lock_path(self.conf))

to the default IP address. This changes test_server_cfn_init to assign

commit_message:
Use AWS::EC2::EIP for test_server_cfn_init

Many (most) clouds won't have the assumed network to directly ping/ssh
to the default IP address. This changes test_server_cfn_init to assign
a floating IP, and use that to ping and ssh to the server.

It also moves the ping to the end of the test. This was initially
meant to catch regressions in a co-gated neutron, but it is no longer
required for a heat-only test.

Change-Id: Ia9404289b2f9632883a479ccb435cbf6c51fcf2f

Create external address setting for maas checks

commit_message:
Puppet: Configure neutron_api_class on controller

We're already configuring Neutron in Overcloud, but the controller
is still configured to use the default Nova neutron_api_class for
default configuration for networking, which means it used Nova Network
and not Neutron. This causes some of the Nova API is_neutron
checks to behave incorrectly.

This patch updates the controller to use nova::network::neutron (like
we already do on the overcloud_compute.pp role). As part of the change
several of the compute specific hiera settings for the
nova::network::neutron class have been moved to common.yaml.

Change-Id: Id2d5a5a0aa1ca087de714880ef1ea98484b06849
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/43/163543/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update volume type name for volume type API

This continues the change for updating volume type to
include changing name.

- Updated the following APIs and tests for volume type

* update volume type
PUT http://<openstackhost>:8776/v2/${tenant_id}/types/${vol_type_id}
body
{
    "volume_type": {
      "name": "test_updated",
      "description":"updated_desc"
    }
}

** user can update name
** if update name, name can not be empty spaces.
** if update name, can not change the name to be the same as the one
in another volume type
** name and description can not be both None

Implements: blueprint volume-type-description
Change-Id: Idc08f796932df709ff20c17f6bc8d4753d85ad3c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/06/140906/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # volume type name is unique, if change to a name that belongs to # a different volume_type , it should be prevented check_vol_type = None try: check_vol_type = \ _volume_type_get_by_name(context, values['name'], session=session) except exception.VolumeTypeNotFound: pass if check_vol_type and check_vol_type.get('id') != volume_type_id: raise exception.VolumeTypeExists(id=values['name'])

subject: Integrate OSprofiler and Trove
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-25 15:36:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/ac3fb0afcd01d0bdc0e8ba17f2f6209a5ef2ced5', 'message': 'Integrate OSprofiler and Trove

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request.
*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of service
Initialize and set an openstack.common.notifier based notifier
instance to osprofiler which be used to send notifications to
Ceilometer. After Trove changed to use olso.messaging (change
Ibd886f3cb4a45250c7c434b3af711abee266671c), will refactoring to
use olso.messaging based osprofiler built-in notifier instead.
*) Use profile enabled context in services interaction
Change service API to pass profile context in, rpc server will
use trace info to initialize their profile context to continue
the profiling for the request as a transaction. The callee could
use continually trace info which server returned as well.
*) Add tracing on service manager and sqlalchemy db driver object

NOTE to test this:
You should put to localrc:
  RECLONE=no
  CEILOMETER_NOTIFICATION_TOPICS=notifications,profiler
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-acompute,ceilometer-acentral
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-anotification,ceilometer-collector
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-alarm-evaluator,ceilometer-alarm-notifier
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-api
You should use python-pythonclient with this change:
  I5a76e11d428c63d33f6d2c2021426090ebf8340c
Run any command with --profile SECRET_KEY
  $ trove --profile SECRET_KEY create 1
  # it will print <Trace ID>
Get pretty HTML with traces:
  $ osprofiler trace show --html <Profile ID>
note that osprofiler should be run from admin user name & tenant.

Change-Id: I580cce8d2b3c4ec9ce625ac09de6f14e1249f6f5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-25 16:25:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/705aa0ecbe3789e6e4263000d8e00a707a929831', 'message': 'Integrate OSprofiler and Trove

  I5a76e11d428c63d33f6d2c2021426090ebf8340c
You should use devstack with this change to setup notification
options automatically:
  I80a6ad5841ea4a8d36bcf89eade4d782cccd50f0
Run any command with --profile SECRET_KEY
  $ trove --profile SECRET_KEY list
  # it will print <Trace ID>
Get pretty HTML with traces:
  $ osprofiler trace show --html <Trace ID>
note that osprofiler should be run from admin user name & tenant.

We prepared a common BP in oslo-spec due to integration change is
similar to all projects: I95dccdc9f274661767d2659c18b96da169891f30
Currently there are 2 other projects are using osprofiler: Glance &
Cinder, and some others are working in progress.

Change-Id: I580cce8d2b3c4ec9ce625ac09de6f14e1249f6f5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2014-09-22 16:01:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/9f85f403741c50aa093f7413c040c322932aff09', 'message': 'Integrate OSprofiler and Trove

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows
secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and add first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request.
*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of service
Initialize and set an openstack.common.notifier based notifier
instance to osprofiler which be used to send notifications to
Ceilometer. After Trove changed to use olso.messaging (change
Ibd886f3cb4a45250c7c434b3af711abee266671c), will refactoring to
use olso.messaging based osprofiler built-in notifier instead.
*) Use profile enabled context in services interaction
Change service API to pass profile context in, rpc server will
use trace info to initialize their profile context to continue
the profiling for the request as a transaction. The callee could
use continually trace info which server returned as well.
*) Add tracing on service manager and sqlalchemy db driver object

NOTE to test this:
You should put to localrc:
  RECLONE=no
  CEILOMETER_NOTIFICATION_TOPICS=notifications,profiler
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-acompute,ceilometer-acentral
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-anotification,ceilometer-collector
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-alarm-evaluator,ceilometer-alarm-notifier
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-api
You should use python-pythonclient with this change:
  I5a76e11d428c63d33f6d2c2021426090ebf8340c
You should use devstack with this change to setup notification
options automatically:
  I80a6ad5841ea4a8d36bcf89eade4d782cccd50f0
Run any command with --profile <SECRET_KEY>
  $ trove --profile <SECRET_KEY> list
  # it will print <Trace ID>
Get pretty HTML with traces:
  $ osprofiler trace show --html <Trace ID>
note that osprofiler should be run from admin user name & tenant.

Idce1c327c6d21a767c612c13c1ad52a794017d71 .
  
We prepared a common BP in oslo-spec due to integration change is
similar to all projects: I95dccdc9f274661767d2659c18b96da169891f30
Currently there are 2 other projects are using osprofiler: Glance &
Cinder, and some others are working in progress.

*) Use profile enabled context in services rpc interaction
Change context serializer to pass profile context to service,
rpc server will use trace info to initialize their profile context
to continue the profiling for the request as a transaction.
*) Add tracing on service manager and sqlalchemy db engine object

NOTE to test this:
You should put to localrc:
  RECLONE=no
  CEILOMETER_NOTIFICATION_TOPICS=notifications,profiler
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-acompute,ceilometer-acentral
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-anotification,ceilometer-collector
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-alarm-evaluator,ceilometer-alarm-notifier
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-api
Run any command with --profile <SECRET_KEY>
  $ trove --profile <SECRET_KEY> list
  # it will print <Trace ID>
Get pretty HTML with traces:
  $ osprofiler trace show --html <Trace ID>
note trace showing can be executed with admin account only.

Currently there are 2 other projects are using osprofiler: Glance &
Cinder, and some others are working in progress.

commit_message:
Integrate OSprofiler and Trove

*) Add osprofiler wsgi middleware
This middleware is used for 2 things:
1) It checks that the person who wants to trace is trusted and knows
the secret HMAC key.
2) It start tracing in case of proper trace headers
and adds the first wsgi trace point, with info about the HTTP request.

*) Add initialization of osprofiler at start of service
Initialize osprofiler with oslo.messaging notifier which
is used to send notifications to Ceilometer.

*) Use profile enabled context in services rpc interaction
Change context serializer to pass profile context to service;
rpc server will use trace info to initialize their profile context
to continue the profiling for the request as a transaction.

*) Add tracing on service manager and sqlalchemy db engine object

NOTE to test this:
You should put to localrc:
  CEILOMETER_NOTIFICATION_TOPICS=notifications,profiler
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-acompute,ceilometer-acentral
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-anotification,ceilometer-collector
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-alarm-evaluator,ceilometer-alarm-notifier
  ENABLED_SERVICES+=,ceilometer-api

Run any command with --profile <SECRET_KEY>
  $ trove --profile <SECRET_KEY> list
  # it will print <Trace ID>
Get pretty HTML with traces:
  $ osprofiler trace show --html <Trace ID>
Note: Trace showing can be executed with the admin account only.

The change to enable Trove exchange in ceilometer has been merged:
Idce1c327c6d21a767c612c13c1ad52a794017d71 .

The change to enable profile in python-troveclient has been merged:
I5a76e11d428c63d33f6d2c2021426090ebf8340c

We prepared a common BP in oslo-spec as the integration change is
similar in all projects: I95dccdc9f274661767d2659c18b96da169891f30
Currently there are 2 other projects are using osprofiler: Glance &
Cinder, and some others are a work in progress.

Change-Id: I580cce8d2b3c4ec9ce625ac09de6f14e1249f6f5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/53/116653/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osprofiler from trove.common import cfg from trove.common import profilefrom trove.openstack.common.rpc import serializer as rpc_serializerclass RpcServiceProfileSerializer(rpc_serializer.Serializer): def serialize_entity(self, context, result): prof = osprofiler.profiler.get() if prof: trace_info = { "hmac_key": prof.hmac_key, "base_id": prof.get_base_id(), "parent_id": prof.get_id() } if isinstance(result, dict): result["trace_info"] = trace_info else: result = {"trace_info": trace_info, "__result": result} return result def deserialize_entity(self, context, entity): trace_info = context.to_dict().pop("trace_info", None) if trace_info: osprofiler.profiler.init(**trace_info) return entity osprofiler.profiler.trace_cls("rpc")(self.manager_impl) serializer = RpcServiceProfileSerializer() manager=self.manager_impl, serializer=serializer) profile.setup_profiler(binary, host)

commit_message:
Allow to provide timeout for snapshot generation

removed automatic retries, they can cause duplication of tarballs
even when snapshot can not be generated in given timeout

Change-Id: I4c5fec5d72d2ed76528d1b03d878ca0572e012f2
Closes-Bug: 1414059
